messages.content: I want to derive an impactful paper that will encourage people to continue research on post traumatic growth as well as have some direct takeaways for how we create work and learning environments. I would like to dervice this paper from the research I've done for my master's. I will share my thesis and some writing, and I'd like your help in assessing the core ideas that might be the most interesting and compelling. ask me 5 questions to help you help me come up with a great concept for a paper and a brief outline, as well as potential journals that might be interested. I'm attaching some documents, please reveiew them and ask me questions to help me prompt best into a paper I'm proud of

attachments.extracted_content:
Wamda Article 1:
The version shared
with them is here.
The Journey Towards Entrepreneurial Wellbeing and
Impact
by Bilal @ Bloom.pm • Sept 22, 2023
Introduction: Rethinking Trauma and Resilience
2020 is a dicult year to forget. It was the year COVID highlighted the importance of
mental health globally, the year of the Beirut Blast, and when we felt the rumblings of
global financial destabilization. Entrepreneurs find and exploit risk, but what happens
when risk-taking is compounded by a world in flux? What lessons are we learning from
the last few years, and how can entrepreneurs and ecosystems adapt? Join me in this
series of posts to explore answers to these questions, bridging wellbeing and impact.
Page 1 of 14

Let's begin by delving into how this evolving landscape has impacted my work and
perspectives, beginning with a project focused on character strengths.
From Character Strengths to Crisis Response
In July 2020, through my non-profit Bloom.pm I was operating a virtual accelerator for
youth in Lebanon, supporting education-focused social enterprises with support from
the Asfari Foundation. As a graduate student at the University of Paris - Learning
Planet Institute, I researched Character Strengths,first described by Positive
Psychology researchers Christopher Peterson and Martin Seligman. I was hoping to
find out how these factors related to leading a flourishing life and might be connected
to entrepreneurial success.
Then, on August 4, 2020, everything changed. When the Beirut Port Explosion rocked
the city, it forced me to think about mental health and wellbeing in a new way.
This sudden shift in focus wasn't unique to us; studies conducted in the region revealed
that entrepreneurs at large were grappling with similar challenges.
Building Resilience: Lessons from Lebanon and Beyond
The tragedy had a profound impact, upending lives and altering the course of many
entrepreneurial journeys. Faced with a combination of crises—the Beirut blast, the
COVID-19 pandemic, political revolution, and economic collapse—many who had once
been committed to building their future in Lebanon felt compelled to seek stability
and security elsewhere.
The Konrad Adenaur Stftung researched why people were leaving their businesses
and moving out of Lebanon. They found that between large and small businesses, 38%
can’t cope with the stress of everyday life and are prioritizing their mental health.
Over 65% are leaving for quality of life and safety abroad.
Page 2 of 14

Konrad Adenaur Stftung Foundation - Braving the Storm, Safeguarding tThe
Lebanese Economy Page 20
Research in Action - Leaving The “Lab”
Through the active research I was conducting with my teams, I found that my work on
wellbeing and flourishing wasn’t an “extra”, it was in fact supporting their
entrepreneurial efforts. At Bloom, we started hosting sharing circles, online breathwork
courses, art therapy, chi gong, and workout classes for entrepreneurs in our programs.
We started asking entrepreneurs how they were feeling and began to support each
other in a new and deeper way. The data was adding up - the entrepreneurs who were
taking action towards their holistic wellness in the face of diculties were the ones
who persisted with their businesses and were happier too!
Since the Arab Spring, I’ve been working on building the entrepreneurial capacity of
the MENA entrepreneurship ecosystem. Starting with technical skills through my work
on maker/hackerspaces and today through my work with Bloom and our
personal/professional growth accelerators. As ecosystem builders, we must address
entrepreneurs' need - perhaps more than others - for wellbeing support. And we're not
alone in recognizing the significance of this issue; recent research has brought the
mental health crisis among MENA entrepreneurs into sharp focus.
Page 3 of 14

Recent studies make this clear, including 2021 research by Wamda, Microsoft for
Startups, EMPWR, and H.A.D Consultants, which sheds light specifically on the mental
health challenges facing entrepreneurs in the MENA region. That research exposed
that, along with economic uncertainty and social upheaval, almost 36% of founders
described their mental health as 'bad.' Additionally, while 44.2% spend at least two
hours a week decompressing, less than 10% feel their mental state is in a good place.
The survey drew heavily from the region's wealthier, more stable nations, with over
50% of respondents from the UAE alone. KSA and Jordan together comprised another
22%. Perspectives from less prosperous MENA countries were limited in the dataset.
Take Action: Join The Wellbeing Survey and Learning Conference
Let’s build a healthier, more impactful ecosystem together! I invite you to join our
action-oriented research by taking the Wellbeing at Work Survey.
With your input, we can begin to “diagnose” where our ecosystem is struggling with
wellbeing so that we can find the medicine we need. What might we do to help our
organizations, governments, and companies bring more wellness to individuals, teams,
organizations, and communities?
We are hosting an in-person Wellbeing for Impact Learning Conference in Lebanon
on Sept 29. We’d love to see you there to discover the survey's preliminary results, and
experience workshops and sessions highlighted by a growing body of research
demonstrating that taking care of ourselves is good for business.
Page 4 of 14

In 2021, Wamda, in collaboration with Microsoft for Startups, EMPWR and H.A.D
Consultants conducted a study assessing the impact of COVID on the
entrepreneurship ecosystem mainly in the UAE. They found that the MENA region is a
hotspot for multiple challenges, including economic downturns and political unrest.
Amidst this, research by psychologists Richard Tedeschi and Lawrence Calhoun shows
that it's possible for both individuals and organizations to experience post-traumatic
growth. At Bloom, we're focused on leveraging this potential to create resilient
ecosystems.
Suggested addition: I'm one of the co-founders of Bloom.pm, an accelerator that operates out
of Lebanon regionally through its virtual entrepreneurship programs. In the last years, since
the economic collapse, the revolution and protests, the Beirut blast and the devaluation of the
currency, we have seen many people leaving Lebanon to find their fortunes elsewhere. What I
wonder is: do they have to?
Page 5 of 14

Cultivating Growth with Bloom: A Hands-On Approach
Suggested addition: Many organizations and businesses and governments would prefer to
continue to operate in Lebanon, in Morocco, in Tunis, in all of these places. And especially for
me, importantly, I am originally from Iraq, and my parents wanted me to grow up in Iraq, but
they couldn't because of the wars. And so ever since I was young, I always wondered, is it
possible to build in these regions? Some research by ArabNet and the Conrad Stiftung
Foundation has indicated that many people have left Lebanon and left their businesses, and
a big reason is they're unable to cope with the stress of everyday life and prioritize their
mental health. They're also moving abroad in search of quality of life and safety and security.
All of these things are big components of well-being and decent work.
Join the Movement: Participate in Our Well-being at Work Survey
At Bloom we are working on a wellbeing at work survey to help us understand the
wellbeing gaps in the entrepreneurship ecosystem in the Middle East and to then
support the training organizations with resources and tools to help their teams
address those needs. Imagine someone aspiring to cross a river.
Imagine you’re trying to swim across a river and you don’t know how to swim. You can
either jump and start splashing…. Or you can get a better perspective, understand the
terrain, learn to swim and then flow. This metaphor embodies our approach at Bloom,
nurturing environments where individuals and organizations can navigate the
challenges of our times with grace and ecacy.
Page 6 of 14

Your participation will help shape strategies and interventions that foster
post-traumatic growth in our workplaces, creating environments where individuals,
businesses, and communities flourish synergistically.
We invite you to be a part of this survey. Your insights will help chart a path of growth
and resilience and inspire a future where wellness and success coexist harmoniously in
our work environments. [Insert link to the survey here]
Conclusion: Building a Future Where People and Planet Thrive
Page 7 of 14

As we forge ahead in these tumultuous times, the experiences from regions like
Lebanon serve as reminders: mental health diculties are an inevitable facet of our
journey, especially for entrepreneurs.
Recently, the MENA region has served as a crucible, demonstrating the raw and often
untapped potential of post-traumatic growth. This concept, illuminated by researchers
Richard Tedeschi, PhD, and Lawrence Calhoun, PhD, revolutionizes our understanding
of resilience, emphasizing that true growth often blossoms from the ashes of trauma.
At Bloom, we are embarking on a mission to facilitate this growth, fostering
environments where individuals and organizations don't just bounce back but leap
forward, fully equipped to navigate the intricacies of an ever-changing world.
The Expatodus: Unravelling the Underlying Triggers
Before we forge ahead, it is vital to understand the depth of the existing crisis in
areas like Lebanon, where a significant fraction of the workforce seeks refuge and
opportunities abroad. Recent data uncovers alarming trends:
● About 66% prioritize moving abroad for a better quality of life
● Around 68% are seeking security and safety overseas
● 55% are drawn by superior financial opportunities abroad
● 38% find it imperative to prioritize their mental health, unable to cope with
daily stresses in the region
Understanding these nuances is critical as we devise strategies to foster
post-traumatic growth, creating ecosystems that retain talent and nurture it to its
fullest potential.
Beyond Resilience: The Path of Post-Traumatic Growth
George Bonanno's seminal research on resilience reveals a profound insight: resilience
is commonplace. A minority navigate the pathways of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder
(PTSD), but a golden segment experiences post-traumatic growth. This growth
signifies an elevation, a flourishing that comes with having navigated the complexity
of trauma.
Bonanno advocates for identifying and bolstering the factors that propel individuals
towards this growth trajectory, moving beyond theoretical constructs to practical,
real-world applications. This approach aims to foster what is often termed as
"antifragility", presenting a tangible pathway to thriving amidst adversity.
Original Audio:
Page 8 of 14

In 2020, I was running an entrepreneurship training program for social enterprises in Lebanon
working in education with support from the Asfari Foundation. I was taking the
Entrepreneurship Character Strengths Assessment from the School of Positive Psychology, the
Values in Action Characters profile, to see if I could figure out the correlates for
entrepreneurship in character traits to understand which ways of being led to persistent and
successful entrepreneurs. Yet in the middle of this experiment, in the middle of this training,
there was the Beirut terrible explosion that destroyed much of the city and shattered the
dreams of many of the entrepreneurs in my program. While initially my research was
attempting to identify the qualities, the ways of being that bring us to life, that bring us a
sense of fulfillment and flourishing, and support us as well in creating healthy entrepreneurial
projects, I suddenly found myself also confronted with the reality of trauma. And I thought
that it would be potentially of service to the entrepreneurs in my program, the entrepreneurs
that I work with in Lebanon and Iraq and the Middle East and North Africa and in all the
places in the world that are experiencing great change and also sometimes trauma as we just
saw in Morocco and in Libya. And as we know, none of us are exempt and in our fast
changing futures, who knows when we will be confronted with diculty. So the question came,
is it possible to identify the qualities that support people growing through the diculty? And
it turns out that in the scientific literature, there is a factor less known than post-traumatic
stress disorder called post-traumatic growth. And I began exploring the factors that relate to
post-traumatic growth and how to bring them into the entrepreneurship programs I'm working
on.
And so after that experience and understanding that there are factors that are correlated
with growth after a trauma, in today's trauma-informed culture it seems like every day there's
a news article talking about resilience, trauma, and the importance of having a
trauma-informed environment. The fact is most people are actually resilient. It is the norm. If
you check out Bonanno's work you will see that resilience is what happens in the middle of the
bell curve. There is a small minority that wind up having diculties and that's what we call
post-traumatic stress disorder, people that have long-term negative repercussions, and then
there are another small minority that have long-term positive growth outcomes from the
experience of diculty. My question was can we begin to identify those factors and then can
we create environments in our entrepreneurship ecosystem, in the entrepreneurial training
programs, in our workplaces, in our organizations, in our schools to help us prepare for when
the inevitable is bound to happen. We in the past had different support networks around us.
As someone who currently works from home and lives far from family and from my dearest
friends, I know that my work environment is a big part of my social and and emotional
stability. How can we create workplaces that both promote goodness for the individual while
simultaneously creating positive business outcomes and especially for social entrepreneurs
positive environmental and social impact without burning out the people in our organizations?
The research is clear. The data is coming back over and over and over again from the Gallup
polls about disengaged workers costing trillions of dollars to the global economy that the time
is now to take care of ourselves so that we can take care of our businesses and communities
and create the change that we want to see in the world.
I'm one of the co-founders of Bloom.pm, an accelerator that operates out of Lebanon
regionally through its virtual entrepreneurship programs. And we have seen in the last years,
since the economic collapse, since the revolution and protests, since the Beirut blast, since the
devaluation of the currency, many people leaving Lebanon to find their fortunes elsewhere.
Page 9 of 14

The question is, do they have to? Many organizations and businesses and governments would
prefer to continue to operate in Lebanon, in Morocco, in Tunis, in all of these places. And
especially for me, importantly, I am originally from Iraq, and my parents wanted me to grow
up in Iraq, but they couldn't because of the wars. And so ever since I was young, I always
wondered, is it possible to build in these regions? Some research by ArabNet and the Conrad
Stiftung Foundation has indicated that many people have left Lebanon and left their
businesses, and a big reason is they're unable to cope with the stress of everyday life and
prioritize their mental health. They're also moving abroad in search of quality of life and
safety and security. All of these things are big components of well-being and decent work. This
is why we are conducting a well-being at work survey, where we would like to identify what it's
like in the ecosystem today. What might we be able to do to help our organizations, our
governments, and us as individuals within our companies to bring more wellness to us
individually, to our teams, to our organizations, and to our communities? Some things we
cannot change: we cannot prevent a tsunami or a natural disaster. But we can change how we
talk to each other about it. In my research, it shows that that is actually a bigger determinant
of whether or not the diculties help us grow or collapse.
So back in 2020, immediately after the blast, I was unable to pull myself away from my
computer, trying my best to coordinate rescue efforts, data collection, supporting non-stop,
until my friend took my laptop away from me, took my phone away from me, and forced me
to take a break. It wasn't until then that I realized that I had been overstressing, that I hadn't
been sleeping or eating, and that I had been increasingly more effective, more and more
ineffective, and less effective over time. And that there's a difference between exerting energy
and making progress. Sometimes I like to give the example of someone in the water who
doesn't know how to swim splashing and making a mess, versus someone who has taken
lessons and uses far less energy but is making it to the other side of the shore. And that is
what I would like to bring to our entrepreneurship ecosystem. With this survey, identifying how
to bring positive change, starting with the individual, moving to the relational, and then out
into the organizational. How can we bring practices that will help us enhance the strength and
resiliency of our ecosystem and increase the likelihood that when something happens, we'll be
prepared?
In my research on post-traumatic growth and the factors, I found that two really important
factors are:
First, people have a strong social network. That means that our oces cannot be places where
we don't trust our colleagues, where we are having back-oce gossip, where we don't
understand the intentions of our leadership. We need to create an environment of deep and
meaningful relationships at work. This will be the first place that will create a buffer between
whatever is happening and how we feel about it.
Secondly, learning internal conversational skills called deliberate rumination. Intrusive
rumination is complaining about what is happening and saying, why is this happening to me?
Deliberate rumination is asking, accepting what is happening, what can I do about this
situation? And talking to each other about it.
Page 10 of 14

Entrepreneurship Amidst Adversity
In 2020, I led a training program for people starting businesses in Lebanon. We focused on
education and got help from the Asfari Foundation. I took a test from the School of Positive
Psychology to learn about character traits that make good entrepreneurs.
But then, there was a big explosion in Beirut. It hurt the city and many people's dreams. My
work changed because now we also had to deal with trauma.
I wondered if there were qualities that could help people grow through hard times. I found out
about something called post-traumatic growth, which is not as well-known as post-traumatic
stress disorder.
Now, my goal is to explore how these factors can be part of our entrepreneurship programs
around the world where challenges are faced by everyone at some point or another during
their journey towards success..
Resilience in Work and Life
After learning that some people grow after going through hard times, we often hear about
the importance of being strong in tough situations. Most people are actually good at handling
problems. Only a few have long-lasting troubles and others become better because of them.
Can we find out what helps us handle diculties? And can we make our schools, workplaces,
and other places ready for when bad things happen? In the past, we had more support from
family and friends around us. But now many of us work far away from them or even from
home.
How do we make workplaces that help each person while also helping the business succeed?
This is important for businesses that want to create a positive impact on society without
making their workers feel too tired or stressed.
The research shows it's time to take care of ourselves so that we can take care of our
businesses and communities. By doing this, we can create the change that will make the world
a better place.
Bloom.pm: Rebuilding Businesses Locally
Page 11 of 14

I am a co-founder of Bloom.pm, an accelerator that helps people start businesses in Lebanon
and nearby areas. In recent years, many people have left Lebanon because of problems like
the economy, protests, and the Beirut blast. They are looking for a better life somewhere else.
But do they really need to leave? Many groups want to keep working in places like Lebanon,
Morocco, and Tunis. I come from Iraq myself but had to move away when I was young because
of wars. Since then, I've wondered if it's possible to build something good in these regions.
Research shows that many people leave their homes and businesses due to stress and not
feeling safe or happy where they live. That is why we started a survey about well-being at
work. We want to learn what it's like for people today so we can help make things better for
everyone.
We know we can't stop big events like natural disasters from happening. But how we talk
about them with each other can make us stronger instead of tearing us apart
Eciency Through Balanced Work-Life
In 2020, after a big event, I couldn't stop working on my computer. My friend made me take a
break. That's when I learned that working too much can make you less effective.
Think about someone who doesn't know how to swim but uses lots of energy splashing around
versus someone who swims well and gets to the other side easily. This is what we want for our
business world.
With this survey, we want to find out how to improve things by starting with ourselves, then
our relationships, and finally in our organization. We need strong social networks at work
where people trust each other and avoid gossiping or misunderstanding their leaders'
intentions.
We also need good thinking skills called deliberate rumination instead of just complaining
about problems (intrusive rumination). Deliberate rumination means accepting what's
happening and asking what can be done about it while talking with others.
--------

attachments.file_name: Character Strengths And Fostering PTG (draft to publish).pdf
attachments.extracted_content:
Character Strengths and
Fostering Post-Traumatic Growth
A Research Report Developed During The First Edition Of The
Asfari Challenge For Social Innovation
Page 1 of 11

2020 brought many challenges to the already challenging field of Social
Entrepreneurship, especially in Lebanon, with the global pandemic, on top of local
challenges of the economic collapse, political instability, shortages of foods and
medicines, unemployment, and the August 2020 explosion at the port of Beirut.
In our programs and for impact monitoring, we use the Values in Action Character
profile (VIA), which offers perspectives on aspects of being that make life worthwhile
and supports us in finding ways to help bring out people’s strengths in pursuit of their
social entrepreneurial aims.
Our research found that well-being and life satisfaction correlate with self-efficacy and
productivity. The more teams feel resourced to face the challenges of life and work,
even in chaotic times, the better the outcomes for the teams and their social initiatives.
Bloom's research team conducted qualitative and quantitative research to
contextualize the changes seen within the Character Strengths of our participants.
Reviewing the data in the context of the challenges that people in Lebanon have faced
over the last year, we raised the question: How may our programs impact the people
who were part of our programs?
We are interviewing participants who went through the complete 6-month (planned
initially as four months) Accelerator Program (May to October 2020) and those who only
went through the two-week Sprint Program (in April 2020) to deepen the
understanding of how people respond to and grow through challenging situations and
how those responses differ within a program and outside a program. We are doing this
to identify better the factors that lead to post-traumatic growth (PTG is defined below)
and then to include these factors more deeply in our programming.
This report describes a recently identified buffering effect for participants within the
ACSI program on the measure of Character Strengths overall and a more substantial
buffering effect on Well-being and Life Satisfaction factors.
TABLE OF CONTENTS
Post-Traumatic Stress vs Post-Traumatic Growth 3
Evidence from the ACSI Program 4
Quantitative Evidence 4
Quantitative Evidence 7
Practical Program Applications of Our Hypotheses 9
Further Exploration 9
References 11
Page 2 of 11

Post-Traumatic Stress vs Post-Traumatic Growth
Trauma and the accompanying stressors that persist do impact many people who go
through an acute traumatic event, such as the blast that went off in Beirut last year, or
sustained challenges, such as those emerging from the pandemic, economic collapse,
and others. Individuals may have trouble concentrating, flashbacks, sensitivity to similar
situations, and other negative experiences that develop after a traumatic event are
called Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). The research shows that after a traumatic
event, there are three primary responses:
1. A small percentage of people who experience it develop PTSD,
2. The majority of people show resilience and return to the pre-event state,
3. Another minority demonstrates something called Post Traumatic Growth.
(Jeon 2015)
In Post-Traumatic Growth (PTG), after a traumatic event spent grappling with the
challenges, there is a period of growth whereby people develop new strengths, see new
possibilities, grow spiritually, develop closer relationships, and have a deeper
appreciation for life.
These days, more programs are becoming trauma-informed and adapting accordingly,
but there is little inclusion in entrepreneurship programs and little research focusing on
how entrepreneurship programs can better support communities during and after
traumatic events and post-traumatic growth. In an age of disruption and “new
normals,” understanding what supports PTG is critical.
Page 3 of 11

Evidence from the ACSI Program
To explore this further in the context of our programs, we have recently analyzed the
Character Strengths profiles of people who went through our ACSI Sprint+Accelerator
program versus those who just went through the ACSI Sprint Program.
For this cohort of participants, we have primary quantitative data collected at the
beginning of the Sprint period (April 2020). We then selected a subset of teams for the
longer 4-month Accelerator program, which we extended to six months due to the
challenges in Lebanon and beyond.
It is important to note that these are small-scale studies with 13 participants within our
accelerator program and 17 participants within the Sprint-only program.
Quantitative Evidence
We conducted the same quantitative assessment from December 2020 to January
2021, with the initial results shared here.
From an aggregated view, the ACSI program seemed to prevent a drop in overall
character strengths. We collected samples of the ACSI Sprinters' character strengths
profile at the beginning of the program during the sprint period. We re-assessed
people who participated only in the Sprint and participants who completed the ACSI
Accelerator program.
By comparing the pre/post changes across all 24 Character Strengths, we see that the
ACSI teams that were part of the Accelerator program had a slight .2 point increase in

which experienced a .6 point drop.
This exploration led to identifying that the impact of our program had a more

The table above indicates the traits the Research team is putting forward to explore
deeper integration into programming.
Gratitude is interesting because it has a high correlation with well-being and life
satisfaction, and it is one of the traits the program can improve.
Hope and Persistence have been demonstrated to be malleable Character Strengths
(Gander, 2019) and also have high correlations with Entrepreneurial Success (Worell,
2011) as well as Life Satisfaction (Park et al., 2004) and well-being (Gander, 2019).
We hypothesize that the combination of the trait's malleability and correlations with
factors that can support entrepreneurs make these traits good candidates for
strengthening throughout a program.
Quantitative Evidence
The qualitative analysis consisted of twenty-one 1.5-hour interviews, all conducted
remotely and recorded digitally. The interviewees were divided into ten people from
outside the training program and 11 who had gone through the training program.
After the Beirut Explosion, many of the interviewees were feeling angry. Although
anger may be seen as a negative state, many participants used their anger towards a
factor we called Revolutionary Ideation.
“Angry at the government, of course. Angry that the city I love was destroyed.
The nice things about our city were destroyed in a second because of the
irresponsibility of the people governing. Of course, I went to the protest that
happened immediately after” - Interview 006
Some people went to the streets to protest, while others viewed their entrepreneurial
activity as their “action” in response:
“With the revolution came many different revolutions... one of the revolutions we
are making is in education. And I say that I am an activist and not on the
ground - it is our revolution in education. I do not think the revolution is only
about going down and doing it violently. It is about rethinking, unlearning,
recreating. Putting aside everything traditional / forced upon us / trying to make
a difference. not just to make money. Money is not the aim, it is the reward. It is
not the reward I am aiming for. The impact is the aim I want. There have been
lots of revolutions in media, education, and feminism/sexuality. This awareness
is coming out and has been a social revolution, not only (taboo). Not just a gov
/political revolution; it is everything. This is my revolution.”
-Interview 019
Resilience inspires action and engagement as an antidote to the potential freezing
reflex. While focusing on character strengths development has been shown to support
well-being factors described by PERMA (Goodman & Kauffman, 2017), a subset stands
out in our interviews. The components of this subset are hope, humor, self-regulation,
social intelligence, and teamwork. We can see that these are especially correlated with
resilience and may be interesting to explore in future studies.
Page 7 of 11

Traumatic events are destabilizing to the individual since they can shatter mental
models, self-image, and worldviews, and while the possibility of rebuilding these offers
a potential avenue for change and positive growth for the individual given the right
context, environment, and support (Roepke, A. M., & Seligman, M. E. P. 2014) how
people choose to respond is highly variable. In the previous section, we described
people who engage (flight). This time, let us discuss migration (flight).
Flight is an inevitable response that many people have when something tragic
happens. Before the blast, Lebanon had a migration challenge. World Bank data
indicates that about 40 percent of male and 30 percent of female university graduates
leave Lebanon upon graduation (World Bank 2014). While it is still too early to tell what
the migration impact of the explosion will be, the total population of Lebanon dropped
by .44% last year, and (Ibrahim, 2020) reports that the number of people leaving
Lebanon increased by about 30% in the first month after the blast. Understanding the
decision-making process of social entrepreneurs is critical since they are an important
part of the population working on creating stability and positive reasons for people to
stay, either through their services, as employees, or as customers.
This snippet of dialogue from an interview demonstrates the importance of holding
multiple perspectives in real time and ends with a contradiction: a desire to want to
stay.
“For instance, if I had kids. If I was in Beirut/ lost a close family member, I may
have thought I would leave. Fortunately, I do not; it relates to how much they
can take. My brother is leaving for France in September, so I cannot leave
everyone/my family. We have a family business, and my father is relatively old.
And I want to stay here willingly.”
-004 Interview
The third response individuals have in the face of an overwhelmingly negative situation
is to freeze. In our interviews, we identified the initial stages after the blast, where many
people felt stuck, expressing exasperation and frustration at the situation, indicating
they sensed a loss of control. These aspects connect to Posttraumatic Growth (PTG) by
negating the opposite, posttraumatic stress. Some of the symptoms of PTS are freezing,
feeling numbness, an inability to act or care, holding one’s breath, and a sense of
dread…
While it is important not to overstate the case of PTS, most people respond quite
resiliently, as proposed by (Bonanno et al., 2004). Also, for people to experience the
positive effects of PTG, even the challenges and stressors of ordinary life can be enough
of a trigger to stimulate benefits (Ewert et al.; S., 2019).
“... It is useless. They are not serving us by doing this. (Sharing news about the
situation) They are producing anger that cannot turn into anything. The people
are already angry about the economic issue. They do not have proof. One can
sit and do theories for hours.”
017 Interview
“Khalas (an exasperated form of “enough” in Arabic). I cannot control anything…
I need to control my feelings and thoughts.

-020 Interview
Practical Program Applications of Our Hypotheses
A key objective of our programmatic approach in Bloom is to combine these critical
aspects of character and universal skills development into our entrepreneurial support
programs since the success of social impact and traditional enterprises is intimately
connected to the team's capacities, especially founding and early team, of an
enterprise. The more effective programs can be in terms of enterprise and personal
development factors, the more impactful the programs can be in the short- and
long-term. This is even more critical in emerging ecosystems and
marginalized/vulnerable communities where character and skill development
opportunities are less available and where exposure to acute and sustained traumatic
experiences is more common.
Further Exploration
Further exploration will tackle how to deepen the factors supporting these traits and
engender post-traumatic growth in an age of instability and chaos. Social Support and
Deliberate Rumination correlate with increased potential for Post Traumatic Growth
(Morris et al.; J., 2011).
(Morris, B. A., & Shakespeare-Finch, J. 2011).
The programmatic implications of the factor analysis above and the strengths
assessment open lines of inquiry about the potential benefit of a conscious discussion
of strengths.
Page 9 of 11

Deliberate Ruminating is the process of choosing the questions and thoughts one has
around a traumatic event, such as “What is the lesson I am learning through this?” This
is in contrast with Intrusive Ruminating and Brooding, which may take the tone of
“Why is this always happening to me?”
Including moments of Deliberate Rumination in a social setting where trust is first
established can potentially support PTG. Including a focus on Strengths that support
individuals' sense of life satisfaction and overall well-being is hypothesized to set a state
of mind conducive to positive Deliberate Rumination.
A traumatic event is destabilizing to the individual since it can shatter mental models,
self-image, and worldviews. The possibility of rebuilding these offers a potential avenue
for change and positive growth for the individual given the proper context,
environment, and support (Roepke et al., M. E. P. 2014). Throughout one’s life, the
majority (> 60% across many countries) of people will experience an event that they
report as traumatic (Scott et al., 2013).
The chart above shows that traumatic events offer individuals transformational
potential. Bloom believes that Social Entrepreneurship programs can provide the
scaffolding to support the development of PTG, personal growth, and positive societal
impact.
By engaging individuals with New Possibilities (Roepke, A. M., & Seligman) through
their enterprises, offering positive social support, facilitating moments of collective
positive rumination, and making visible and encouraging growth of the Character
Strengths that promote life satisfaction and well-being.
Programs that consider this are hypothesized to support individuals going through
trauma and create framing that helps guide them toward becoming personal
transformational experiences that lead to societal transformational experiences.

1/ Context
Bring to the table and describe the object/thing/phenomenon you decide to study.
Entrepreneurship education is a methodology gaining traction in sustainable
development as a persistent way to increase employment, reduce inequality, and

M2 Lesc 20-21 - U.E. Research Project - A. Legavre & N. de Chanaud
increase stability. In these countries, the entrepreneurial landscape is non-ideal due
to the additional challenges within the political and economic landscape. Potential
violence and social unrest entrepreneurs must deal with plus the usual stress and
challenges of operating an enterprise. The additional stressors of an entrepreneur
working in a conflict-prone area on top of the challenges of capitalising and
operating in conditions of uncertainty shine a light on the need to understand
emotion, affect, character strengths and resilience alongside more traditional
economic and entrepreneurial measures.
The insights gained from the edge cases of entrepreneurship education will bear
fruit for educators, policymakers, and multinational NGOs who seek a sustainable
development path. Challenges and stressors confront anyone wanting to create
change and identifying cross-culturally relevant interventions to nurture resilience
and support entrepreneurial orientation, action, and success will be beneficial.
2/ Presentation of references
To clarify the challenges and opportunities presented to governments, universities
and other entrepreneurial ecosystem facilitators this review goes over a subset of the
literature discussing:
● 
Entrepreneurial Intent (Zhao, Seibert, & Hills, 2005),
● 
Entrepreneurial Orientation and Intent
● 
Entrepreneurial Cognition and Action
And viewing them in relation to:
● 
Self-efficacy (Benight & Bandura, 2004)
● 
Resilience / Post Traumatic Growth
● 
Emotion / Affect - as mood and passions (Baron 2008)
● 
And hope - defined as a cognitive capability in as opposed to an emotion
(Arend 2020).
Within this literature review, the following relevant questions were salient in regards
to identifying the factors relating to entrepreneurial intent and action in conflicted
areas:
1. 
What mediates entrepreneurial self-efficacy?
2. 
How do conflict and trauma promote or demote the factors leading to
entrepreneurial motivation and action?
3. 
What interventions enhance the promoting factors and inhibit the demoting
factors leading to entrepreneurial motivation and action?
Concepts

M2 Lesc 20-21 - U.E. Research Project - A. Legavre & N. de Chanaud
Within question 1, we identified the concepts of positive affect (Bernoster et al. -
2020), and metacognition as factors that support entrepreneurial self-efficacy.
Within question 2, we identified the concepts of Post-Traumatic
Growth(Shakespeare-Finch 2011), Brooding VS Rumination (Garcia 2014), and Hope
(as cognitive capability VS emotion).
Conceptual Map Example: Positive Affect mediates between Self Efficacy and Innovative
Behaviors.
Within question 3 we identified the concepts of Signature Strengths training within
the Values in Action Character Strengths model (Schutte and Malouff - 2019),
Reappraisals and positive reinterpretation (Scheier, Weintraub, & Carver, 1986),
Deliberate Rumination, Benefit Finding (Ai et al. 2005), and Social Support.
The surveyed papers demonstrate a lack of specificity between positive affect, life
satisfaction, and happiness (Schutte 2019).
Results
It is clear that affect matters. The literature reviewed demonstrates that positive
affect mediates the relationship between self-efficacy and the innovative behavior of
entrepreneurs. (Mielniczuk 2020) which aligns with (Bandura, 1997)’s explanation of
how self-efficacy enhances wellbeing and outcomes.
(Uy et al. 2017) demonstrated that higher Affect Spin (the dynamics of changing
mood/feelings) impedes progress on entrepreneurial milestones. The impact
remains, regardless of the type of affect Spin - either entirely within the positive
range or ranging from positive to negative. Affect stability is related to wellbeing and
wellbeing pertaining to goal orientation and goal orientation to supporting venture
progress.

M2 Lesc 20-21 - U.E. Research Project - A. Legavre & N. de Chanaud
What inhibits progress for entrepreneurs in conflict and challenged areas? Across
studies, we find that intrusive rumination and brooding stemming from a traumatic
event mediate the relationship between subjective and post-traumatic symptoms
(García 2015). The monitoring that comes from a metacognitive perspective can be
related to intrusive rumination. In (Learning 2015) we see that metacognition is the
mediating factor between Social Support and Wellbeing.
The previous results demonstrate the correlates of affect and internal narrative to
entrepreneurial behaviors and intention. Metacognition also plays a vital role as a
mediator of wellbeing while highlighting a question of the role metacognitive
processes have in types of rumination.
Continuing the explanation of trauma, rumination and wellbeing as factors upstream
to entrepreneurial outcomes (Triplett, Tedeschi, Cann, Calhoun and Reeve 2012)
conducted a path analysis to identify how traumatic experiences lead to increased
life satisfaction. They identified the process of Deliberate Rumination (sometimes
mediated/triggered by Intrusive Rumination) to be a core factor.
Meaning and story making is a subtext across much of the literature read about
trauma and entrepreneurship. It is a concept which underlies rumination in the
previously discussed studies. As described in (Janoff-Bulman 1989) - a traumatic
event may lead to posttraumatic stress due to a break in our assumptive worlds, the

M2 Lesc 20-21 - U.E. Research Project - A. Legavre & N. de Chanaud
schema we come to expect is no longer relevant. Meaning connects things, and
traumatic events and disruption disconnect them (Park 2010). It is becoming clear
that one way Deliberate Rumination supports Post-Traumatic Growth and through
that can support entrepreneurship in the developing world is through the
accompanying resilience of PTG and the reappraisal and the telling of a new story.
The relationship between deliberate and intrusive rumination, affect, and action is
becoming a clear exploration area. (Baumeister and Wilson, 1996) identified four
needs for meaning: Need for purpose, need for value/justification, the need for
efficacy, and finally the need for self-worth. (Bullough et al., 2014) have demonstrated
a relationship between entrepreneurial self-efficacy and resilience with
Entrepreneurial Intent. The integration of self-efficacy between the needs for
meaning and a component supporting entrepreneurial intent demonstrates the
complex web of effects that inspire or dim the light on entrepreneurship
motivations.
Lastly, Posttraumatic Growth is identified through the development of specific
character strengths. (Peterson 2008) demonstrated the development of particular
Character Strengths for individuals who have gone through a traumatic experience
at some time in their lives. Peterson identified this growth an arbitrarily long time
after the traumatic event without conducting an intervention; this is intriguing since
it reinforces the theory (Bonanno 2004) proposes - that resilience and Post-traumatic
growth are the general response most people undergo posttraumatic experience as
a part of the natural healing process. While Bonanno suggests that some
interventions (journaling to help with reappraisal) may encourage Post-Traumatic
Growth, the research demonstrates many paths to PTG and many people find it
independently. An uplifting perspective.
4/ Limits of the existing studies
Measurement challenges:
The majority of the papers in this study used self-reported measures and
recommended alternative approaches to assessing factors. (Bernoster et al. - 2020)

M2 Lesc 20-21 - U.E. Research Project - A. Legavre & N. de Chanaud
Issues with non-longitudinal studies: How to define success? Measuring Self
Efficacy and Resilience, as correlates to Entrepreneurial Intent (Bullough 2013), found
convincing evidence. However, without measuring entrepreneurial behavior and
entrepreneurship impact (jobs created, families sustained, the positive impact of
entrepreneurial activities), the demonstration of the correlation between resilience
and self-efficacy with entrepreneurial intentions opens the doors to longitudinal
studies exploring outcomes of those intentions.
Along with desiring to validate their study across in diverse cultures outside Spain
and Portugal, (Mortan 2014) identified that their research is limited by the shortage
of empirical evidence on the relationship amongst Entrepreneurial Self-efficacy and
how it is related to Emotional Intelligence and Entrepreneurial Intention. (Mortan
2014)
5/ Research question
Some questions emerge after reviewing the literature: How does engaging in an
entrepreneurial task impact emotions - how are they reciprocal? Are there
positive/negative spirals, and how what starts them, stops them, encourages them?
What are the interrelationships between emotion and cognition and entrepreneurial
phenomena (Shepherd, 2015)? What is the relationship between metacognition,
rumination and entrepreneurial self-efficacy?
All important questions. Due to prior acquisition of Character Strengths Data
(pre/post) for people within and without an entrepreneurship program (ACSI)
identifying changes and after the Beirut Blast of 2020, there is an opportunity to ask
a new question:
What factors supported the development of Character Strengths and PTG for
entrepreneurs in Lebanon after the Beirut Blast?
The relevant factors can be determined through qualitative interview referencing
some of the concepts referred to in this literature review (rumination, PTG,

M2 Lesc 20-21 - U.E. Research Project - A. Legavre & N. de Chanaud
metacognition, social support, etc.). A theoretical model will be developed to identify
the strongest correlations that buffered the individuals within the ACSI program
from a 1 point drop in their Character Strengths their peers outside the program
experienced. This knowledge will support other entrepreneurial educators in
similarly challenging environments to improve their programs and support
entrepreneurs working to create a better world. This knowledge will help conflict
zone entrepreneurs grow from their challenges, like a phoenix.

Fight, Flight, Freeze … Or Laugh?
Character Strength Factors Supporting Post Traumatic Growth for
Social Entrepreneurs After a Traumatic Event
Author : Supervisors:
Bilal Ghalib Amélia LEGAVRE

1

June 10, 2021
Thanks to: Hiba, Sarms, Tony, Amelia, Franck, Josephine, Pascal, Ed for your discussions and

2

Abstract
Background: During 2020, the world was challenged by a global pandemic. In Lebanon, the
addition of an economic collapse and a major explosion in the capital city brought acute
stressors, triggering migration ideation. This research analyzes motivation for migration and
social entrepreneurial ideation as well overall wellbeing for social entrepreneurs.
Purpose: In this study, we aim to extrapolate the factors that support social entrepreneurs
wellbeing and motivation by analyzing the relationship between resilience, posttraumatic growth
(PTG), and character strengths within a training program in Beirut.
Methodology: After gathering a broad set of data (pre-post assessments of Character Strengths,
Post Traumatic Growth Inventory, Rumination, Entrepreneurial Intent, Resilience, Impact of
Event - Revised) we conducted a qualitative analysis to assess and tag responses. Correlations
were identified with factors that support post traumatic growth, resilience and social
entrepreneurial ideation.
Findings/Conclusions: While each person’s life journey is unique, we have identified that social
entrepreneurship ideation is promoted by prior traumatic experiences, followed by opportunities
and support for growth. Traumatic experiences are inescapable in life, and the opportunity
educators and trainers have is to understand how to shift the trauma response curve towards
growth. Deliberate Rumination, thinking and reflecting about one’s life circumstances can be
incorporated into group facilitations. Character Strengths are correlated with PTG and there are
validated methods for reliably developing strengths of character. One highly leverable strength is
humor, and one way humor can support growth is by preventing helplessness.
Implications: The results of this study increases an understanding of the complex decision
making individuals face in a crisis, and offers insights into the factors which support
posttraumatic growth and contributing to society through social entrepreneurship. We hope the
3

results of this paper inspire facilitators to incorporate humor, positive structured conversation and
to enliven their program with character development.
Introduction
Homo Sapiens and Neanderthals coexisted for thousands of years. Both species were tool users,
sophisticated in their socialization, and both made seafaring vessels. Yet, there is one crucial
difference : although Neanderthals had the physical technology to cross the seas and spread to
new lands, only Homo Sapiens did. It appears that Homo Sapiens are successful as a species in
part due to our appetite for risk, our ability to sail out into the endless sea with hope for a further,
more profitable shore (Stringer 2012, see figure 1). It might be that our presence on every
continent on Earth is a testimony to our entrepreneurial instinct.
On the other hand, in the mathematical field of dynamical systems theory, the concept of an
attractor is the set of states that draws a system together. Societies and people tend to stay in their
steady states until an extreme situation is thrust upon them, creating an opportunity for creating a
new steady-state system. In (Triplett, K. N., Tedeschi, R. G., Cann, A., Calhoun, L. G., & Reeve,
C. L. 2011) the researchers described the nodes in the dynamical system of someone going
through a traumatic experience as Core Beliefs.
This research paper reviews 21 social entrepreneurs working in Lebanon precisely throughout
such a destabilizing event. Over the year 2020, Lebanese entrepreneurs experienced a failed
popular uprising, the spread of the coronavirus, a currency devaluation, and the Beirut Port
Explosion, which killed over 200 people and injured thousands of others while leaving 300,000
people homeless.
Conducting qualitative and quantitative research to explore the impact of the explosion and
potential for Post Traumatic Growth alongside other factors, this research paper attempts to
analyse the decision making at an inflection point for social entrepreneurs.
In an attempt to create scalable impact from limited dollars, iNGOs (international Non Profit
4

Organizations) are increasingly looking to support social businesses. Market prices track
international events such as wars and famine to extreme weather events, and thus we can make
an assumption about the general volatility of the world at large by reviewing the CBOE Volatility
and the CBOE Volatility of Volatility indexes (see figure 2). Judging from the fact that 2020
experienced the highest rate of volatility in March after the beginning of the coronavirus
pandemic it is evident how market volatility can map to indirect market forces, chaos in the
world. The VOV index shows a slight, yet clear trendline - the world is becoming more volatile.
The US Army War College defined the concept of VUCA (Volatile, Uncertain, Complex,
Ambiguous) during the cold war (UNHCR 2021), and recently announced a new peak in the
number of international refugees, increasing the interconnection of people adding to the
complexity and destabilizing societies. We find trends indicating increased political polarization,
climate change, increasing pandemics and financial instability, and in the face of the lack of
trusted political systems social entrepreneurship is seen as a counterbalancing force, especially
where there already are systemic challenges, like Lebanon. To systematically address the many
global challenges, recently framed by the SDGs (Sustainable Development Goals), many
multinational NGOs and international development organizations are establishing funds and
offering support for social entrepreneurial activities. The vision is to create a triple bottom line
between people, the planet, and profits through social entrepreneurship.
The question underpinning the research on a pool of 21 social entrepreneurs (with half in an
entrepreneurial program and half outside of it) centers on the question: how do we nurture and
motivate social entrepreneurs in a values oriented program? We attempt to answer this question
by understanding the impact of the traumatic event (IES-R) for “fight”, their deliberate and
intrusive rumination amongst social entrepreneurs in Lebanon for “flight” and their potential
resulting growth (PTGI) for “freeze”. We will describe the reasoning for the mapping shortly.
Previous research by Christopher Peterson has demonstrated that improvements in Character
Strengths are correlated with improvements in the Post Traumatic Growth Index, for people that
5

experience major life difficulties (Peterson 2008). And, importantly, there’s a growing body of
evidence that there are character strength interventions that support people in developing their
strengths (Schutte, N. S., & Malouff, J. M. 2018).
This inquiry eventually allowed us to identify factors which support social entrepreneurs along
the three dimensions of responding to the blast: fighting, fleeing or freezing. We’ve mapped
them to the Self Determination Theory (SDT) of Motivation (Deci & Ryan 2008) (Autonomy,
Mastery and Relatedness). This helps us create a map of understanding about how a traumatic
event might influence the motivation of entrepreneurs (SDT), and will give us measures to
understand how to measure change on the relevant variables. Additionally, it gives us tools to
support entrepreneurs in a deeper understanding of themselves and their situations, as well as
tools to help develop the strengths of character that they value - and which will hopefully help
them find flushing in life, no matter the external situations and no matter how they choose to
respond to the crisis.

A subset of character strengths correlate to the above measures and can be interesting areas
for further interventional research.
6

Interestingly, there is only one factor in our study that correlates with social entrepreneurial
ideation, and that is if they have experienced a prior traumatic experience and were able to
describe it articulately during the interview. It seems that trauma can open a door to increase
compassion, reject the traditional narrative of fitting into the economy with a “real job”, and help
people in connecting with a higher purpose. With this as our starting point, we explore the
factors that support people in developing the self awareness and strength of character to grow
after a traumatic experience.

Methodology
We’ve used a qualitative analysis method for the exploration of our research, in an attempt to
identify potentially unseen variables. These unseen variables support the exploration of those
factors that contribute to, or detract from commitment, to social entrepreneurship. The author of
this paper has been able to utilize their position as the head of Research And Development at
Bloom, an organization which operates social enterprise acceleration and education programs.
Prior to the Beirut Port Explosion in August 2020, the participants and applicants for the Bloom
social entrepreneurship accelerator program had already taken the Values In Action Character
Strengths Inventory (VIA-IS). At the conclusion of the four months long accelerator, and
following the Beirut Explosion, the applicants who were not selected as well as the participants
who were a part of the program requested to complete a post-test VIA-IS inventory. An analysis
of the pre/post test data for the VIA-IS demonstrated a buffering effect experienced by
individuals who were a part of the Bloom program, which led to in-program individuals
maintaining their overall VIA average while individuals outside the program experienced a
significant drop. To understand this phenomenon was the genesis of this research, and inspired
the qualitative/quantitative research methodology described below.
Qualitative Analysis:
The qualitative analysis consisted of twenty one 1.5 hour long interviews, which were all
conducted remotely and recorded digitally. The interviewees were split with 10 people coming
from outside the training program and 11 people who had gone through the training program
(marked as “In prog.”). The questions for the interview were segmented into the following
themes:
Topic Key Insight Explored
Introduction and Background Work habits and family entrepreneurial background
Ethnographic Questions What is their educational/ family's income level?
8

Entrepreneurial Intent (EI) What is their level of commitment to entrepreneurship?
Impact of Event Scale (IES-R) What was the level of impact of the Beirut Explosion?
Resilience (BRCS) What is their level of resilience?
Post Traumatic Growth Index
(PTGI)
How much did people grow after the Beirut Explosion?
Rumination Scales What is the ratio of deliberate and intrusive rumination?
Concluding Statements What does entrepreneurship mean in places facing
instability?
The interview consisted of open ended questions as well as questions requesting a qualitative
response. Both questions were answered live on the call, allowing the interviewee to offer deeper
context into the numerical responses. The audio for the interviews were transcribed manually,
and an inductive process was followed to derive codes. The interview corpus was then brought
into a software supporting bi-directional links through which code clusters were identified.
Quantitative Data:
During the semi-structured interview process, alongside the open-ended questions, the
interviewer also gathered quantitative answers for the following measures:
1. Post Traumatic Growth Index (PTGI Tedeschi & Calhoun 1996)
2. The Resilience Coping Scale (BRCS Sinclair and Wallson 2004)
3. The Impact of Event Scale: Revised (IES-R DS Weiss 2007)
4. The Intrusive - Event Related Rumination Inventory (EERI Cann et al., 2011)
5. Entrepreneurial Intention (EI) scale derived from Luthje & Frank (2003); Duijn (2009) /
Krueger et al. (2000)
6. The VIA Inventory referenced above. Peterson, C., & Seligman, M. E. P. (2004)
9

A subset of the codes derived from the interview corpus were identified as meaningful
segmentation markers, and each interview was then tagged in the database for analysis with the
observed value.
Segmentation Tags:
Property Fields Description
Has_Therepist True/False/Unsure Does the individual attend therapy?
Injury_From_Blast True/False/Unsure Was the interviewee injured in the
Beirut Port Explosion?

entrepreneurial family?

using their working life to
contribute to society?

migrating out of Lebanon?
