10

The reasoning behind having a qualitative and quantitative approach was to be able to identify
unforeseen variables through the interviews, while simultaneously having validated measures for
important features like the Impact of The Event Scale (IES-R). This allows us to have a
qualitative comparison point with which to compare interviews and derive insights.
Challenges:
Following an inductive tagging methodology, in which novel categories were derived from
interviews, led to a challenge in which not all participants were asked relevant questions. For
example, it became clear that prior experience with violence - such as living through the 2006
war - may have potential relevance on the responses people had to the current time of tumult.
This observation led some of the data in our table to be segmented to three categories: True,
False and Unsure.
Another challenge came up in regards to perceived social expectations of the interviewer during
the interview, sometimes referred to as Demand Characteristics, a theory expounded on by Orne,
Martin T. (2009). Some participants qualified their responses with statements like: “I only put a
four because I didn’t experience it directly myself.” This happened on repeated occasions with
individuals who seemed to be embarrassed by the fact that they were feeling high levels of
negative impact from the effects of the Beirut Port Explosion, without actually witnessing it
directly, being injured or knowing people who have been injured or killed.
The process of going wide with the qualitative interview and going deep with the quantitative
measures has exposed variables and areas of study that would not have been obvious at the start
of the research process. To add a final note, the VIA-IS assessment was done as an online
questionnaire outside the interview structure allowing us to compare pre-post tests, and with the
entire set of VIA Inventories conducted with 260+ entrepreneurs.
11

Data Analysis and Insights:
Overview of Data and Background Knowledge
After a threatening situation, animals and humans respond in a variety of ways. Initially
described by Walter Cannon (Cannon, W. B. 1915) as the Fight or Flight response, the theory
has since then been adapted by Dr. Stephen Porges into Polyvagal theory (Porges 2009). This
model now includes freezing as an alternative response, and attempts to correlate stress responses
to neurohormonal responses. In the face of a situation in which no options seem viable, an
individual can either choose to fight, flee (flight) or freeze. We will be using these three types of
responses as a framing for potential ways our interviewees responded to the Beirut Blast.
In 2011, Martin Seligman (Seligman 2011) made the hypothesis that PERMA (Positive Emotion,
Engagement, Relationships, Meaning, and Accomplishment) comprises well-being, and argues
that the model is helpful for measurement as well as for application (Seligman 2018).
Before we get into the analysis of the data, please review the prior description of the data and
data gathering phase. If you would like to explore the data yourself, you can find a public dataset
available to review here: http://bit.ly/cs-data-21
The Character Strengths data was gathered as part of the application process for a social
entrepreneurship program before the August 4th, 2020 explosion. After the explosion, to
understand deeper changes in entrepreneurial ideation we conducted a second VIA-IS as well as
a new questionnaire using the new measures described above. To start the exploration as to the
factors which support social entrepreneurs we keep in mind the question: who grows as a social
entrepreneur in times of adversity and who reprioritizes the notion of their career trajectory to
focus more on self preservation. In 2008 Christopher Peterson (Peterson et al. 2008)
demonstrated a positive correlation between the VIA-IS Character Strengths Inventory and the
Post-Traumatic Growth Inventory (PTGI; Tedeschi & Calhoun, 1996). The PTGI measures
growth on the dimensions of Appreciation, New Possibilities, Relating to Others, Spiritual
12

Enhancement and Personal Strength; interestingly, all of these dimensions are relevant for social
entrepreneurial ideation. Comparing PTGI with the Character Strengths assessment we identify
that Humor, Teamwork, Spirituality, Prudence and Judgement have a significant correlation for
PTGI across the five sub-dimensions, see figures below.
Data validity questions.
We initially hypothesized that there would be a correlation between CS prepost (Character
Strengths Difference in average scores assessed before/after the blast) and Post Traumatic
Growth. While there seems to be a slight correlation between CS prepost and PTGI -
Appreciation (.33 p-val .14) we cannot at this time with our limited data make any strong
statements about Character Strength changes before/after an explosion and PTGI. One factor
could be that the time frame for the post test was taken over a 3 month period (December -
March 2020) and it might be interesting to study a progression of changes rather than comparing
pre and post. Growth takes time and measuring over an extended period confuses the data. Also,
assessing people earlier, and therefore closer to the period of the traumatic event may not have
left time to metabolize the experience while people who filled in the assessment later have had
more opportunities. Another bias that may be influencing the data is potentially the types of
people who submit forms early compared to those who wait may also capture proactive people
early in the recovery process and procrastinators later in their process. Rather than adding
another factor to control for procrastination, I propose future assessments to include deadlines for
inclusion into the dataset, or to include time of receipt as an influencing factor.
And now, we begin to explore motivation and wellbeing for entrepreneurs following the Fight,
Flight and Freeze framework.
Fight
After the Beirut Explosion, many of the interviewees were feeling anger. Although anger may be seen as a
negative state, we found that many of the participants used their anger towards a factor we called
13

Revolutionary Ideation, clicking this link will take you to see sections of the interview tagged with this
concept.
“Angry at the government, of course. Angry that the city I love was destroyed. The nice things
about our city were destroyed in a second because of the irresponsibility of the people governing.
Of course I went to the protest that happened immediately after” - Interview 006
Some people went to the streets to protest, while others viewed their entrepreneurial activity as
their “action” in response:
“With the revolution came many different revolutions... one of the revolutions we're making is in
education. And I say that I'm an activist and not on the ground - it's our revolution in education.
I don't think the revolution is only about going down and doing it violently. It's about rethinking,
unlearning, recreating. Putting aside everything traditional / forced upon us / trying to make a
difference. not just to make money. Money is not the aim, it's the reward. It's not the reward I'm
aiming for. The impact is the aim I want. There's lots, revolutions in media, education, revolution
in feminism/sexuality. This awareness is coming out and has been a social revolution not only
(taboo). Not just a gov /political revolution, it's everything. This is my revolution.”
-Interview 019
14

As you can see from the chart above, the majority of participants with revolutionary ideation
came from people who were not intending to leave Lebanon, even after the blast. While
revolutionary thinking and political engagement is not the primary focus of this paper, it is worth
being included here since many of the inspiration for social entrepreneurs comes from areas the
public sector is lacking in, and can be seen as a form of direct action. Most of the social
entrepreneurs interviewed for this paper were operating businesses solving problems in the
domain of education.
Another important reason to consider the idea of “Fighting” and using the feeling of Anger is
that it is a fact bound to happen, especially when paired with major traumatic events. So rather
than avoiding the feeling, we can sublimate anger to increase the critical factor of engagement to
prevent freezing, complacency, and inaction. While the language of fighting is not necessarily
positive, it does imply a high degree of activation and purpose, something important to maintain
in the face of conflict and insurmountable odds.
15

The measure we’ve selected for “Fight” is resilience, labeled BRCS (Sinclair and Walston
2004), it measures the following questions on a 5 point scale:
1. I look for creative ways to alter difficult situations.
2. Regardless of what happens to me, I believe I can control my reaction to it.
3. I believe I can grow in positive ways by dealing with difficult situations.
4. I actively look for ways to replace the losses I encounter in life.
Acting as an antidote to the potential freezing reflex, resilience inspires action and engagement.
While focusing on character strengths development has been shown to support wellbeing factors
described by PERMA (Goodman & Kauffman 2017), there appears to be a subset that stands out
in our set of interviews. The components of this subset are the following : Hope, Humor,
Self-Regulation, Social-Intelligence and Teamwork. We can see that these are especially
correlated with resilience, and may be interesting to explore as in future studies.
What might not support direct engagement? The following table presents negative correlations
between Revolutionary Ideation that we can find identified in the data, there are no strong
positive correlations to present.
16

The relationships that stand out to me are the relationship between Prudence, having a child and
Revolutionary Ideation. Prudent parents are less likely to be engaged in protests and other types
of activism. Another strong correlation is with Spirituality. Diving into how one mother
responded to the explosion we can see both features at play:
“No, nothing changed. God's will will still happen as it should. Nothing has changed. I worked
as a mother to prevent the impact from impacting my children much so they don't stay home
alone. I didn't have much capacity to go to the site to volunteer. Fadi my brother was there and
saw the fire that became the blast and was more present. I personally focused on making sure
my children would cross this situation without harm. Fadi worked on support.”
-013 Interview Spirituality rank 7/24 & Has_Child True
While the strength of Spirituality contributes positively to Post Traumatic Growth through the
“Spiritual Enhancement” facet, there is a concern that over-focusing on the strength of
spirituality could lead to spiritual bypassing, which is a coping strategy where people use
spiritual ideas to avoid facing unresolved emotional issues and development tasks. Spiritual
17

bypassing was coined by John Welwood and developed in (Cashwell, C. S., Glosoff, H. L., &
Hammond, C. 2010).
Interviewee number 18 expressed the balance between trusting in the “Will of God” and
developing and engaging in acts of control like this:
“We do have control over that, if it's going to happen it's going to happen. If maybe we knew
about it, maybe it's going to happen anyway. We're destined to have this. There's a saying in the
(The Islamic Spiritual Tradition), aqqqalal (Arabic for use your brain/do something rational)
watawakal (Arabic for rely on God) - before submitting (to the will of God) do what you have to
do. DO what we should do and at the end of the day what's going to happen is going to
happen.”
-018 Interview
Figure 6 in the figures section below displays an interesting chart exposing some relationships
between meditation, spirituality, revolutionary / social ideation. Spirituality is correlated with not
having a therapist perhaps indicating that people with a stronger spiritual practice don’t identify
with the need to find a therapist. This is interesting because it seems that having a therapist
correlates with deliberate rumination and meditation. Reviewing age seems to indicate that the
younger generations are more open to therapy and meditation alongside their religious and
spiritual beliefs.
One takeaway from the above analysis is that creating mixed communities of practice where
various spiritual, religious, therapeutic ideas are shared openly might create an opportunity for
alternative perspectives to be displayed and their results seen, either amplifying or dampening
the ideas that the group selects as valuable. This might be an important task for course designers
and facilitators to navigate carefully. 013 expressed a value in action by nurturing their child,
while 019 demonstrated Bravery and a rallying cry to contribute socially in a time of
revolutionary change. In relation to the theme of this section, both of them are putting up a good
fight and are engaged in a values informed course of action.
18

Flight
Traumatic events are destabilizing to the individual since it can shatter mental models, self image
and worldviews, and while possibility of rebuilding these offer a potential avenue for change and
positive growth for the individual given the right context, environment and support (Roepke, A.
M., & Seligman, M. E. P. 2014) how people choose to respond is highly variable. In the previous
section we described people who engage (flight), this time, let’s discuss migration (flight).
Flight is an inevitable response that many people have when something tragic happens. Prior to
the blast, Lebanon had a migration challenge where the World Bank data indicates that about 40
percent of male and 30 percent of female university graduates leave Lebanon upon graduation
(WorldBank 2014). While it is still too early to tell what the migration impact of the explosion
will be, the total population of Lebanon has dropped .44% last year and (Ibrahim 2020) reports
that the number of people leaving Lebanon increased by about 30% in the first month after the
blast. Understanding the decision making process of social entrepreneurs is critical since they are
an important part of the population working on creating stability and creating positive reasons for
people to stay, either through their services, as employees or customers.
This snippet of dialog from an interview demonstrates in real time holding multiple perspectives
and ends with a contradiction, to desire to want to stay.
“For instance if I had kids. If I was in Beirut/ lost a close family member I may have thought I
would leave. Fortunately for me I don't’, it’s related to how much they can take. My brother is
leaving for France in September, I can't leave everyone/my family. We have the family business,
my father is relatively old. And I want to stay here willingly.”
-004 Interview
The research strategy was initially going to divide the population into “those who stay and build”
and “those who leave and protect themselves and their families” - during the coding process we
19

found that the decision is emotional some people want to leave and contribute, and some want to
stay and contribute, and many others have competing commitments that are unclear. Sometimes
the interviewee demonstrates deep self knowledge and desires to leave for strategic reasons, to
continue to be able to offer their work life as a service to their community they need to stay safe,
sane and alive:
“I won't lie, sometimes I feel like leaving too. Why do I think about it? To keep this
engine/enthusiasm/giving to people I have to feel secure. Not that I will die at any instant. So
much is online so I can do so much of my work online. I can be effective even if I’m not
physically in the country. I think of my safety, my family… and my earnings. Now I’m fine.
After a while will I still be fine? I’m investing from my income, will I still be able to invest in
my team? That’s the one thing I’m thinking about. I’m investing in the base, raising this “child”
so that one day the company will come and pay me back and take care of me when I’m older.
Thank goodness God has given me a salary. I see tangible results. We’re going to print the book
and sell it and make money from it. I can see it all. It's not like we’re playing and not doing
anything.
-002 Interview
This powerful snippet from the interview shows the strategic process 002 has taken to rationalize
her potential departure from Lebanon. Some questions arise as to how much the combination of
the massive spread of the coronavirus and the subsequent lockdown supports people in their
migration ideation. It could be that as people have spent much of 2020 indoors people now, like
002, have taken their social entrepreneurship programs online and have less of a physical
investment in their physical environments.
Other interviewees have a clearer commitment to leaving and do not seem conflicted in any way:
“I live with my mom/brother. And we are all affected by the situation of course. Because before
that - the port - we already had the economic situation and we were feeling safe since a long time
nothing happened security wise. we heard it could happen again. We don't feel safe anymore.
20

I don't have foreign nationality, so I decided not to take a French one. It's complicated to find a
job, it's a safe thing to do to have a possibility if one has to go outside Lebanon. I would be
interested in leaving if I had an opportunity. Someone said for Canada. Someone said it's very far
and they don't take Lebanese for my age. For security reasons I could go to France for example.
It's a sure avenue, I need a challenge in my life. I don't like routine.”
-Interview 017
“Participants who maintain calm and develop adaptive self-regulating practices Actually my
thinking is everyone is thinking about leaving. Something inside me that doesn't want to leave
despite everything. I don't know why I'm still calm. I see the craziness all around us. The best
thing you can do is focus with what you have, and how you can help others with what you have.
If you focus on all the bad things around us you can't work. What I decided is to help and doing
what I can do and keeping my mental health and family health and that's how to survive
everything. Of course we felt very bad and it was very stressful for us and all these feelings. I
just wanted to stay calm.”
-014 Interview
Albert Bandura’s Social Cognition Theory (Bandura 1989) proposes that a portion of knowledge
acquisition comes from social evaluation, from our data we see that people modulate their
migration ideation based on many factors, one of which is how and who they speak to about it.
Traumatic events disrupt the standard narrative model needing new stories to support meaning,
suggests Neimeyer in (Neimeyer, R. A. (2004), how are those narratives reconstructed? In a
paper developing a model of Post Traumatic Growth for cancer patients (Morris, B. A., &
Shakespeare-Finch, J. 2011) identified Deliberate Rumination as a strong influencing factor for
PTG. Further research demonstrated the relationship between PTG and life satisfaction through
the factor of meaning:
21

In the paper (Triplett et al. - 2012), they demonstrated that the disruption of core beliefs (CBIs)
triggers both intrusive and deliberate rumination and that the destabilizing aspects of a traumatic
event either supports a more meaningful life of satisfaction through deliberately contemplating
the experience, or can negatively affect meaning and life satisfaction through intrusive
rumination.
Deliberate Rumination is the process of choosing the questions and thoughts one has around a
traumatic event, for instance “what is the lesson I am learning through this” in contrast with
Intrusive Rumination and Brooding which may take the tone of “why is this always happening to
me”. We can see both examples in our interview data set. Observe as 018 reflects on discussions
had during a group dialog with other social entrepreneurs in the entrepreneurial training
program:
“...First I was thinking if we stay in this country, I can do anything in this country. Nothing
limiting me, why would I leave this country.... Why ... maybe I should have a backup country if
something unexpected happens. Just having this backup country in mind can help me (with my
project). … Then(the start of the program) (projectName) (personName) starting asking which
country do you want to go to? And I started thinking, first that ... I have friends, good nature,
why leave? Then after the blast I have a different perspective of the country and started thinking
of where I can go when/if something unexpected happens.”
22

--018 Interview
Other examples of social cognition supporting someone positively through social media and
describing the importance of having a community of positive social support to help create a
sense of control and meaning as he adjusts his worldview through the development of spiritual
and meditative practices:
“A lot lot lot lot. After the blast I was majorly helped - writing affirmations. It helped me so
much. I was in complete loss, not knowing what's happening, what the point of anything is. Self
existence questions that you ask yourself. One of the major affirmations, I am control of my
reality even in times of uncertainty.
There's a beautiful instagram, called affirmation addict. Girl in California, I don't have the
application. I have a journal. I have a routine. Every two weeks. I cleanse my home with spiritual
music. I started yoga. More meditation. I did a retreat for 5 days [...]
I always have curiosity to learn more about these. They came at the right time. I have friends
who are more spiritual bess (but) i'm doing it alone. At my own pace. I have a collective of
friends around me that I'm inspired by.”
-020 Interview
Including moments of Deliberate Rumination in a social setting where trust is first established
can potentially support PTG. Including a focus on Strengths which support individuals' sense of
23

life satisfaction and overall wellbeing is hypothesized to set a state of mind conducive to positive
Deliberate Rumination.
The set of character strengths associated with our Deliberate Rumination dimension is
Judgement, Social Intelligence and Teamwork. These traits do intuitively make sense as critical
factors for deliberate rumination and working together as a community to make difficult
collective decisions about traveling, building and relationships. We hope that by bringing a
greater awareness to these strengths of character people and programs will benefit from clearer
thinking and more open discussion on what to do after difficulties arise.
Freeze… or Laugh
The third response individuals have in the face of an overwhelmingly negative situation is to
freeze. In our interviews, we identify initial stages after the blast where many people felt stuck
through expressing feelings of exasperation and frustration at the situation. Indicating they sense
a loss of control. These aspects connect to Post Traumatic Growth (PTG) through negating the
opposite, post traumatic stress. Some of the symptoms of PTS are freezing, feeling numbness, an
inability to act or care, holding one’s breath, a sense of dread…
While it’s important not to overstate the case of PTS, in fact, most people respond quite
resiliently as proposed by (Bonanno, G. A. 2004), also in order for people to experience the
positive effects of PTG even the challenges and stressors of ordinary life can be enough of a
trigger to stimulate benefits (Ewert, A., & Tessneer, S. 2019). Before exploring people’s stress
let’s explore the positive correlations between PTGI and Character Strengths:
24

The majority of the connection comes through the facet of PTGI-Appreciation.
“...It's useless, they are not serving us by doing this. (Sharing news about the situation) They are
producing anger that can't turn into anything. The people are already angry from the economic
issue. They don't have proof. One can sit and do theories for hours.”
017 Interview
“Khalas(exasperated form of “enough” in Arabic). I can't control anything… I need to control
my feelings thoughts rage.
-020 Interview
25

After a month, yeah. In the first month I was consuming a lot of news about it and then I decided
to stop. I was just depressing myself and I couldn't do anything about it and I disconnected
completely and living my life as if nothing was going on. [[Code: Response-Self Protection]] I
wasn't in Beirut, It wasn't as traumatic I was in Sawfar
006 Interview
“I didn't force myself to deal, when I wanted to cry. I was crying, when I didn't feel willing to do
anything I didn't do anything.”
010 Interview
Rather than freezing in response, some of the interviewees exhibited avoidant behaviors, which
parallel freezing:
“After the blast I didn't go to Beirut until just now. It was too heartbreaking, I didn't want to see
it. We were impacted from the protests and the views. I was in a state of denial I didn't want to
believe that this has happened. I only went yesterday because I //HAD// to get a vaccine. In some
buildings you see the effects of the blast, in other buildings it's been cleaned up.”
010 Interview
Contrast the preceding statements with following statements which demonstrate interviewees
engaging in highly motivated activities following the explosion:
“When the blast happened, most businesses closed and people were cleaning up... When I was in
gbeili - company, not antwork. I was looking at the employees and was thinking, don't you want
to be in beirut helping other people? You could just go there and do something, this
paperwork could be done another day.”
019 Interview
26

“I still have nightmares, I have PTSD. Do you really want to know what it's like? I had some
calls with people from projectName. And suddenly the glass office I was in all collapsed and the
couch I was sitting on was full of glass. Allah itlatuf (God intervened with mercy) it was a matter
of minutes. I was caught up on my way down to the floor below with my manager having a silly
discussion when the blast happened. And the whole lower floor was full of blood, everyone had
to be taken to the hospital. We were so scared to move. Because there were two we expected a
third. We all thought we were being blasted. Because of this we created a (product in response),
it was a determination for us that (curseword) it we're staying. We're doing this for the country
despite all the (curse) we're living through. It was created after the blast as a demonstration
that we want to manufacture here, we want to create jobs, we want to build something for the
kids that are deprived of toys, their childhood even.”
https://roamresearch.com/#/app/EntrepreneurialResearch/page/ISYEjUAMD
Aggregating the pre-post tests from all the assessments we have before and after the blast, we
found that by segmenting our assessments by individuals in the entrepreneurial training program,
they have - on average - a one point increase in the measure of Humor in the VIA-IS inventory,
over the course of the program. While Humor may be under-studied in academia, it correlates
with the CS prepost variable in our dataset.
“CS Prepost” is a measure of the overall change in Character Strength before and after the Beirut
Port Explosion. In the following table, we observe that humor and creativity both are factors
affecting the preservation of Character Strengths. We used JASP and a classical regression
matrix since the variables are all continuous variables.
So what is a theory behind humor and this buffering effect? Humor has been linked to adaptive
coping and keeping a “light attitude” in the face of adversity (Ruch and Hofmann 2017). Humor
is also an active response to take when other options are unavailable: people “break” the silence
with laughter, for example. This may be preventing the processes which lead to Learned
Helplessness. Learned helplessness is one way to view the opposite of post traumatic growth for
27

people living in highly chaotic and destabilized situations. Initially Learned Helplessness theory
implied that dogs experiencing inescapable shocks learned helplessness and persisted in helpless
behavior even when the situation became escapable later.
Recent research has shed light on the neurological underpinnings of learned helplessness which
has application in uncertain times (Maier, S. F., & Seligman, M. E. P. 2016). Previously Learned
Helplessness, as the name suggests, theorized that higher level mammals learn helpless behaviors
when they are given inescapable negative experiences. Passivity in the face of a changed
situation, a situation where it behooves the animal to take action, is the hallmark of learned
helplessness. And while that behavior doesn’t change, our understanding of how it comes to be
has. Mammals, when confronted with prolonged adverse situations, develop an unlearned
response of passivity. It is possible to overcome this bias towards passivity by learning and
exerting control. What behaviors are available to act on?
One additional mechanism could have explanatory strength is the Broaden and Build theory
(Fredrickson B. L. 2004) which espouses that positive emotions support people in expansive
activities, and taking action builds new capacity for further positive emotion, expansive activities
and capacities. Humor combines the psychological insight and research from Fredrickson with
the neurological understandings of modern Learned Helplessness theory from (Maier, S. F., &
Seligman, M. E. P. 2016). We can see that Humor is correlated with an overall growth of
character strengths from before and after the blast(CS prepost). Humor stands out as one of the
only factors that is directly connected to growth and stands out as a unique lens to look at both
PTG(PTGI) and Resilience(BRCS) as it ties them all together as can be seen in the following
28

chart:
The court jester is the only person able to speak the truth when there is a crippling fear gripping
the court. Humor breaks the ice and we propose that it may also help sustain the neurological
basis for control. Humor is one of the factors we are exploring in this paper along the dimension
of growth, the other is self reflection and emotional reappraisal through Deliberate Rumination
and the third is Engagement as manifested in anger/political action as well as social
entrepreneurial ideation.
Humor, Engagement & Deliberate Rumination
Conclusion
In conclusion, we investigated the Character Strength correlations with Resilience, Post
Traumatic Growth and Deliberate Rumination. Since Character Strengths are correlated with
Post Traumatic Growth and Wellbeing, and since there is a collection of applied interventions
with scientific validity, we hope this analysis helps educators working inside and outside
conflict. The idea of “pre-silience” (pre+resilience) applies here with the recommendations for
actions being more helpful in situations before there is a traumatic event.
Let’s review the frame and identify the correlated character strengths:
29

Heading SDT Measure ->
Support
Correlated Character Strengths
Fight Engagement
anger/political
social
entrepreneurial
ideation.
Autonomy Resilience ->
Engagement
Hope, Humor, Self-Regulation,
Social-Intelligence and Teamwork.
Flight Deliberate
Rumination
self reflection
and emotional
reappraisal
Relatedness Deliberate
Rumination ->
Dialog
Judgement, Social Intelligence and
Teamwork.
Freeze Growth
Humor
Competency PTGI -> Growth Appreciation of Beauty, Fairness,
Humor, Judgement, Leadership,
Modesty/Humility, Perspective,
Prudence, Social Intelligence,
Spirituality and Teamwork
The strengths that correlate with motivation and wellbeing with the highest correlations are
Teamwork, Social Intelligence and Judgement.
The total list of strengths which emerged from our analysis is:
1. Appreciation of Beauty
2. Fairness
3. Hope
4. Humor
5. Judgement
6. Leadership
7. Modesty/Humility
30

8. Prudence
9. Perspective
10. Self-Regulation
11. Social Intelligence
12. Spirituality
13. Teamwork
Everyone makes different decisions after a traumatic event, one size does not fit all in terms of
how best to design a pedagogy for social entrepreneurs. We hope this paper inspires more
exploration around increasing motivation and wellbeing before the traumatic event, generating
“presilience” so that when challenges come the psychological and social support are already in
place.
One thing is becoming more clear, it’s important to create spaces for truth speaking in the social
entrepreneurship community, we must talk about our failures and fears as well as our successes.
These spaces can be where people explore ways of being and inspire each other through positive
open discussion around Character Strengths. These spaces could be a counter to the negativity
bias seen on both social and traditional media. They offer a facilitated space to practice
deliberate rumination with the positive guidance of facilitators. It also supports the spread of
value-laden idioms, aphorisms, and other easily digestible ideas, which become heuristics for
decision making.
The Character Strengths above come from a small sample study and the correlations do not
imply causation. I hope this paper inspires others to take an applied approach to character
strengths explorations and also publish their data openly to build up a stronger evidence base for
Character Strengths interventions.
31

I hope these findings make their way into communities of practice where social entrepreneurs
can collectively support each other to create the next viable steady-state system wherever they
are.
I want to end with two insights, one from one of the participants of the study and one from a
famous author:
“...Values are the base of every human reaction and really, there's courage and motivation in
every person that's hidden and this very sad event created or awakened values in people. Those
of compassion and courage, of motivation of solidarity and nationalism. Inspire nationalism even
as people as they leaving the country. The people that are leaving the country, they still say my
dream is to come back one day to Lebanon.
Maybe they will go and come back.”
--Interview 017
“If you want to build a ship, don't drum up people to collect wood and don't assign them tasks
and work, but rather teach them to long for the endless immensity of the sea.”
-Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
32

messages.content:
Thank you for sharing your research and writings on post-traumatic growth and its applications in entrepreneurship education and support programs, especially in challenging contexts like Lebanon. I've reviewed the documents you provided, including your master's thesis, a draft article for Wamda, and your literature review. This is fascinating and important work. To help guide you towards developing an impactful paper, here are five questions:

1. Your research identified several character strengths that correlate with post-traumatic growth, resilience, and entrepreneurial motivation, such as humor, teamwork, spirituality, and social intelligence. How might entrepreneurship educators and support organizations deliberately cultivate and leverage these specific strengths in their programs and interventions?

2. The concept of "pre-silience" (pre+resilience) preparing entrepreneurs before challenges occur is intriguing. What might be some key elements and best practices of pre-silience training? How early in the entrepreneurial journey should this be incorporated?

3. You mention the importance of creating spaces for entrepreneurs to engage in deliberate rumination, reflect on challenges, and inspire each other. What are some examples of how this could be structured and facilitated effectively in an entrepreneurship program? What resources or tools might help?

4. Focusing on entrepreneur wellbeing seems to have both individual and societal benefits, contributing to the sustainability of social enterprises working on crucial issues. How can we make the case to funders, policymakers and other stakeholders to prioritize and invest in entrepreneur mental health and support systems?

5. The buffering effect against declining character strengths for entrepreneurs in the support program is a key finding. To what do you attribute this "protective factor" - the curriculum, the relationships and social support, the act of deliberately reflecting via the research, or something else? What implications does this have for entrepreneurship program design?

In terms of an outline, here's a potential structure:

I. Introduction 
- The challenges facing entrepreneurs, especially in volatile contexts
- Post-traumatic growth as a framework 
- Character strengths and their correlation to PTG and entrepreneurial success

II. Cultivating Key Character Strengths
- Overview of key strengths identified in research
- How entrepreneurship programs can develop and leverage these strengths
- Specific interventions and practices  

III. Building "Pre-silience" 
- Concept of pre-silience and rationale
- Key elements and timing of pre-silience training
- Examples and best practices

IV. Creating Reflective Spaces
- Importance of deliberate rumination and group reflection 
- Structuring and facilitating reflective spaces
- Resources and tools 

V. Prioritizing Entrepreneur Wellbeing
- Individual and societal benefits 
- Making the case to stakeholders
- Systemic changes needed

VI. Program Design Implications  
- Protective factors promoting character strengths
- Curriculum, relationships, reflection
- Wellbeing measures and holistic support

VII. Conclusion
- Entrepreneur support ecosystem of the future
- Call for further research and implementation 

Some potential outlets for this work:
- Journal of Positive Psychology 
- International Journal of Wellbeing
- Journal of Social Entrepreneurship
- International Journal of Entrepreneurial Behavior & Research
- Journal of Business Venturing Insights

I'm happy to further discuss and refine the focus and framing for the paper. This research has the potential to make a meaningful contribution to how we develop and support resilient, impactful entrepreneurs in challenging times and places. Let me know if you have any other questions!

messages.content: that sounds a bit ambitious for one paper - ask me 3 questions to determine an appropriate subset and come up with 15 different potential titles for my paper based on my answers and the content you have above

messages.content:
Absolutely, let's narrow the focus to create a more targeted paper. Here are three questions to help determine the most compelling and impactful subset of your research:

1. Which finding or insight from your research do you feel has the most immediate practical application for entrepreneurship education and support programs?

2. Is there a particular aspect of your research that has been less explored in the existing literature and could make a novel contribution to the field?

3. Considering the current global context and challenges, what message or theme from your work feels most urgent and relevant to share with educators, entrepreneurs, and support organizations?

After reviewing the research and materials you provided, here are five potential clusters of concepts that could be developed into separate papers, each with a unique focus and contribution:

Cluster 1: Character Strengths and Entrepreneurial Success
- Correlation between specific character strengths and post-traumatic growth, resilience, and entrepreneurial motivation
- Interventions to cultivate key character strengths in entrepreneurship programs
- Assessing and leveraging entrepreneur character strengths for targeted support

Potential Titles:
1. The Resilient Entrepreneur: Key Character Strengths for Navigating Adversity and Achieving Success
2. Cultivating Entrepreneurial Strengths: Interventions for Developing Resilience, Growth, and Motivation
3. Aligning Support with Strengths: Assessing and Leveraging Entrepreneur Character Profiles for Targeted Development
4. The Character of Success: Exploring the Correlation Between Specific Strengths and Entrepreneurial Outcomes
5. Beyond Grit: The Role of Character Strengths in Entrepreneurial Resilience and Growth

Cluster 2: Humor as a Resilience Strategy
- The role of humor in preventing learned helplessness and promoting a sense of control
- Incorporating humor into entrepreneurship education and support programs
- Humor as a coping and bonding mechanism for entrepreneurs facing challenges

Potential Titles:
1. Serious About Humor: The Role of Laughter in Entrepreneurial Resilience and Wellbeing
2. Punchlines and Punchbacks: Leveraging Humor to Prevent Learned Helplessness in Entrepreneurs
3. The Lighthearted Entrepreneur: Incorporating Humor into Education and Support Programs for Resilience
4. Laughing in the Face of Adversity: Humor as a Coping and Bonding Tool for Entrepreneurs
5. Resilience is No Joke: The Serious Benefits of Humor for Entrepreneur Wellbeing and Success

Cluster 3: Social Support and Entrepreneurial Resilience
- The importance of relationships and social connection for entrepreneur wellbeing and resilience
- Structuring entrepreneurship programs to foster supportive communities
- The role of peer support and mentorship in navigating entrepreneurial challenges

Potential Titles:
1. In It Together: The Critical Role of Social Support in Entrepreneurial Resilience and Success
2. Stronger Together: Building Supportive Communities in Entrepreneurship Programs for Resilience
3. The Connected Entrepreneur: Leveraging Relationships and Social Support to Navigate Challenges
4. Resilience Through Relationships: The Power of Peer Support and Mentorship for Entrepreneurs
5. No Entrepreneur is an Island: Cultivating Social Connection for Wellbeing and Resilience

Cluster 4: Entrepreneurship and Social Change in Challenging Contexts
- The role of entrepreneurs in promoting stability and positive change in volatile environments
- Supporting social entrepreneurs to build resilience and create impact
- The societal benefits of prioritizing entrepreneur wellbeing and resilience

Potential Titles:
1. Agents of Change: Supporting Social Entrepreneurs to Build Resilience and Create Impact in Challenging Contexts
2. From Chaos to Creation: The Role of Entrepreneurship in Promoting Stability and Positive Change
3. Resilient Revolutionaries: Nurturing Social Entrepreneurs as Catalysts for Transformation
4. Entrepreneurship as Activism: Building Resilient Ventures for Social Change in Volatile Environments
5. The Ripple Effect: How Supporting Entrepreneur Wellbeing Benefits Society in Challenging Times

Cluster 5: Spirituality and Meaning-Making in Entrepreneurial Resilience
- The role of spirituality and faith in providing a sense of purpose and perspective for entrepreneurs
- Incorporating spiritual practices and meaning-making into entrepreneurship support
- Navigating the balance between spiritual coping and avoidance in the entrepreneurial journey

Potential Titles:
1. The Spiritual Entrepreneur: Finding Meaning and Purpose in the Face of Adversity 
2. Faith and Fortitude: The Role of Spirituality in Entrepreneurial Resilience and Perseverance
3. Soulful Startups: Incorporating Spiritual Practices and Meaning-Making into Entrepreneurship Support
4. The Double-Edged Sword: Navigating the Balance Between Spiritual Coping and Avoidance for Entrepreneurs
5. Purposeful Ventures: How Spirituality and Meaning-Making Fuel Entrepreneurial Resilience and Impact

These clusters and potential titles offer a range of directions to further explore and develop your research insights. Let me know if any of these spark your interest or if you'd like to discuss other possibilities!

messages.content:
I understand your desire to focus on the unique insights and contributions from your own research. Let's revisit the key findings and concepts that emerged from your work to identify potential paper topics that highlight your original contributions to the field.

Based on your research, some of the most novel and impactful insights seem to be:

1. The buffering effect of the entrepreneurship support program on character strengths during times of crisis, suggesting a protective factor that warrants further exploration.

2. The correlation between specific character strengths (such as humor, teamwork, spirituality, and social intelligence) and post-traumatic growth, resilience, and entrepreneurial motivation, which could inform targeted interventions and support strategies.

3. The concept of "pre-silience" and the potential for entrepreneurship education to proactively build resilience and prepare entrepreneurs for future challenges, rather than solely focusing on post-traumatic growth.

4. The role of deliberate rumination and social support in promoting entrepreneur wellbeing and growth, and the opportunity to intentionally incorporate these practices into support programs.

5. The importance of considering the societal and systemic implications of entrepreneur resilience and wellbeing, particularly in contexts of conflict, instability, and social division.

With these key insights in mind, here are three potential paper titles, subtitles, and abstracts that highlight the unique contributions of your research:

Title 1: Building Buffer Zones in Beirut: The Protective Role of Entrepreneurship Support Programs in Resilience and Growth

Subtitle: An Empirical Analysis of the Relationship between Character Strengths, Crisis Response, and Entrepreneurial Motivation

Abstract:
This paper examines the impact of entrepreneurship support programs on participant character strengths and resilience during times of crisis, drawing on data collected before and after the Beirut Port explosion of 2020. The findings suggest that involvement in a structured entrepreneurship program had a significant buffering effect on participants' character strengths, mitigating the decline observed in a control group. Specific character strengths, such as teamwork, spirituality, and social intelligence, were also found to correlate with measures of post-traumatic growth, resilience, and entrepreneurial motivation. These results highlight the protective role of entrepreneurship support programs and underscore the importance of cultivating key character strengths in building entrepreneur resilience and growth. Implications for program design and implementation in contexts of crisis and instability are discussed.

Title 2: Leveraging Character Strengths for Entrepreneurial Resilience: A New Framework for Targeted Support Interventions

Subtitle: Insights from an Empirical Study of Lebanese Entrepreneurs in Times of Crisis

Abstract:
Entrepreneurial resilience is a critical factor in navigating the challenges and uncertainties of startup ventures, particularly in contexts of political instability, economic disruption, and social upheaval. This paper proposes a new framework for understanding and cultivating entrepreneurial resilience based on the targeted development of specific character strengths. Drawing on empirical data from a study of Lebanese entrepreneurs before and after the Beirut Port explosion of 2020, the authors identify significant correlations between character strengths such as humor, teamwork, spirituality, and social intelligence and measures of post-traumatic growth, resilience, and entrepreneurial motivation. The paper argues for the integration of character strength assessment and development into entrepreneurship education and support programs, and outlines a set of targeted intervention strategies aligned with the proposed framework. Implications for theory and practice are discussed, along with directions for future research.

Title 3: From Post-Traumatic Growth to Pre-Resilience: Reframing Entrepreneurship Education for Proactive Development

Subtitle: Lessons from an Empirical Study of Resilience and Growth in Lebanese Entrepreneurs

Abstract:
This paper challenges the dominant paradigm of entrepreneurial resilience as primarily a reactive process of post-traumatic growth, and proposes a proactive approach to building "pre-resilience" through entrepreneurship education and support programs. Drawing on insights from an empirical study of Lebanese entrepreneurs before and after the Beirut Port explosion of 2020, the authors introduce the concept of pre-resilience as the proactive cultivation of character strengths, skills, and mindsets that enable entrepreneurs to navigate future challenges and uncertainties. The paper identifies specific character strengths, such as teamwork, spirituality, and social intelligence, that were found to correlate with measures of post-traumatic growth, resilience, and entrepreneurial motivation, and argues for their intentional development in entrepreneurship curricula and support interventions. Strategies for fostering pre-resilience, including deliberate rumination practices and social support structures, are explored. The paper concludes with implications for entrepreneurship theory, educational practice, and support program design, and calls for a paradigm shift towards proactive resilience development in the face of increasing global challenges and uncertainties.

These titles, subtitles, and abstracts aim to highlight the unique contributions and insights from your research, while also situating them within the broader context of entrepreneurial resilience, education, and support in times of crisis and uncertainty. Please let me know if any of these directions resonate with you, or if you would like me to refine or explore alternative angles based on your feedback.

messages.content:
Based on your monologue, I have identified several key insights that connect your research findings to the broader literature on post-traumatic growth, entrepreneurial resilience, and support strategies. These insights highlight the importance of deliberate rumination, social support, character strengths, and proactive skill development in fostering growth and resilience in the face of adversity.

Core golden insights:
1. Spirituality can serve as a catalyst for deliberate rumination, prompting entrepreneurs to seek meaning and growth in the face of challenges.
2. Social support and character strengths such as teamwork and social intelligence are crucial for promoting deliberate rumination and post-traumatic growth.
3. Entrepreneurship education can be designed to cultivate character strengths and skills that support post-traumatic growth, such as zest, humor, and relationship building.
4. Engaging in entrepreneurship can help individuals maintain a sense of agency and purpose in the face of chaos, but it is essential to frame stress as positive (eustress) rather than negative.
5. Diverse networks, relationships, and funding sources provide entrepreneurs with resources and support to navigate challenges and promote resilience.
6. Sharing circles and practicing vulnerability can foster connections and growth among entrepreneurs.

Based on these insights, I have developed three distinct paper concepts that explore different facets of entrepreneurial resilience and growth:

Title 1: Cultivating Entrepreneurial Resilience: The Role of Character Strengths and Social Support in Post-Traumatic Growth

Subtitle: Insights from a Study of Lebanese Entrepreneurs in Times of Crisis

Introduction:
This paper investigates the relationship between character strengths, social support, and post-traumatic growth among entrepreneurs in Lebanon, drawing on empirical data collected before and after the Beirut Port explosion of 2020. The findings suggest that specific character strengths, such as teamwork, social intelligence, zest, and humor, along with robust social support networks, play a crucial role in promoting deliberate rumination and growth in the face of adversity. The paper argues for the intentional cultivation of these strengths and support structures in entrepreneurship education and support programs to foster resilience and growth.

Conclusion:
The insights from this study underscore the importance of proactively developing character strengths and social support networks to promote entrepreneurial resilience and post-traumatic growth. By designing entrepreneurship education and support programs that prioritize the cultivation of key strengths such as teamwork, social intelligence, zest, and humor, along with fostering diverse relationships and resources, we can better equip entrepreneurs to navigate challenges and find meaning and growth in the face of adversity. This research calls for a shift towards a more holistic and proactive approach to entrepreneur development, one that recognizes the interconnectedness of personal and professional growth in the face of uncertainty and crisis.

Title 2: Navigating Chaos and Uncertainty: Entrepreneurship as a Pathway to Resilience and Agency

Subtitle: Strategies for Reframing Stress and Cultivating Proactive Skills in Entrepreneur Development

Introduction:
In an increasingly volatile and uncertain world, entrepreneurship can serve as a powerful tool for individuals to maintain a sense of agency, purpose, and resilience in the face of chaos. However, the high levels of stress inherent in entrepreneurial pursuits can also pose significant risks to well-being and growth if not properly managed. This paper explores strategies for reframing entrepreneurial stress as positive (eustress) and cultivating proactive skills and mindsets that support resilience and growth. Drawing on insights from a study of Lebanese entrepreneurs navigating political and economic instability, the authors propose a framework for entrepreneurship education and support that emphasizes the development of key character strengths, diverse networks and resources, and practices of deliberate rumination and meaning-making.

Conclusion:
As global challenges and uncertainties continue to mount, it is increasingly essential to equip entrepreneurs with the skills, mindsets, and support systems needed to navigate chaos and find purpose and growth in the face of adversity. By reframing entrepreneurial stress as an opportunity for growth (eustress) and proactively cultivating key character strengths, diverse networks, and practices of deliberate rumination, entrepreneurship education and support programs can play a vital role in fostering individual and community resilience. This research offers a timely and practical framework for entrepreneur development in an age of uncertainty, one that recognizes the transformative potential of entrepreneurship as a pathway to agency, adaptability, and positive change.

Title 3: The Power of Connection: Fostering Entrepreneurial Resilience through Sharing Circles and Vulnerability

Subtitle: Lessons from a Study of Social Support and Growth among Lebanese Entrepreneurs

Introduction:
In the face of adversity and uncertainty, social connection and support can be a lifeline for entrepreneurs seeking to build resilience and find growth. This paper explores the role of sharing circles and vulnerability practices in fostering entrepreneurial resilience, drawing on insights from a study of Lebanese entrepreneurs navigating the aftermath of the Beirut Port explosion of 2020. The findings suggest that creating safe spaces for entrepreneurs to share their experiences, challenges, and emotions can promote deliberate rumination, meaning-making, and post-traumatic growth. The authors propose a model for integrating sharing circles and vulnerability practices into entrepreneurship education and support programs, highlighting the benefits for individual and collective resilience.

Conclusion:
The insights from this study underscore the transformative power of social connection and vulnerability in fostering entrepreneurial resilience and growth. By creating safe and supportive spaces for entrepreneurs to share their experiences and emotions, we can tap into the collective wisdom and resilience of entrepreneurial communities and promote deliberate rumination and meaning-making in the face of adversity. This research calls for a paradigm shift in entrepreneurship education and support, one that recognizes the importance of social and emotional dimensions of growth and resilience alongside technical skills and knowledge. By integrating practices of sharing and vulnerability into entrepreneur development programs, we can cultivate the social fabric and collective resilience needed to navigate an increasingly uncertain and interconnected world.

messages.content: ask me 5 questions to help narrow it down, pretend you're a phd advisor

content.text: ask me 5 questions to help narrow it down, pretend you're a phd advisor

messages.content:
As your PhD advisor, I want to help you narrow down your focus and select the most promising direction for your research. To do this, please answer the following questions:

1. Which of the key insights (spirituality, deliberate rumination, entrepreneurial stress, or the power of connection) do you feel most passionate about exploring further, and why?

2. Considering the current state of research in the field, which of these insights do you believe has the most potential to make a novel and significant contribution to our understanding of entrepreneurial resilience and growth?

3. Based on your own experiences and observations working with entrepreneurs in Lebanon and beyond, which of these insights seems to resonate most strongly with the real-world challenges and opportunities facing entrepreneurs today?

4. From a practical standpoint, which of these insights do you feel has the most potential to inform the design and implementation of effective entrepreneurship education and support programs?

5. Finally, considering your own strengths, interests, and goals as a researcher, which direction aligns best with your long-term research agenda and the impact you hope to make in the field of entrepreneurship and resilience studies?

During 2020 the world was challenged by a global pandemic, in Lebanon, the addition of an economic collapse and a major explosion in the capital city brought acute stressors which triggered migration ideation. This research explores migration ideation and self-preservation at the expense of social entrepreneurial placemaking with a population of social entrepreneurs in a training program. ","uid":"8FOqdBo2A","create-time":1622091646208,"edit-time":1622097290016},{"string":"**Purpose: ** In this study, we aim to extrapolate the factors that inspire social entrepreneurial placemaking by analyzing the relationship between resilience, posttraumatic growth (PTG), and character strengths within a training program in Beirut. Our conclusions are meant to inspire a more structured approach to sustainable development through entrepreneurship support funding and programming. ","uid":"nKhj4gms-","create-time":1622091652362,"edit-time":1622097132097},{"string":"**Methodology/Approach: ** Using pre-post assessments of character strengths analysis to identify resilience over the course of the Beirut Blast ","uid":"Pfhfs-bTq","create-time":1622091656865,"edit-time":1622097363082},{"string":"**Findings/Conclusions: ** While individual differences and life circumstances have a significant influence on Post Traumatic Growth factors there are programmatic recommendations for funders, trainers and researchers working in social entrepreneurship.","uid":"ADkvYESkD","create-time":1622091662573,"edit-time":1622092023866},{"string":"**Implications: ** The results of this study increases an understanding of the complex decision making individuals face in conflict zones and offers insights into the factors which support post traumatic growth and contributing to society through social entrepreneurship.","uid":"oovYaAyYZ","create-time":1622091668999,"edit-time":1622091821142}],"refs":[{"uid":"zo7TT8UsW"}],"string":"Abstract::","uid":"9DtkfbT6_","create-time":1622091499457,"edit-time":1622091502075,":block/refs":[{":block/uid":"zo7TT8UsW"}]},{"children":[{"string":"Sustainable development has been focusing on using entrepreneurship as one if it's main approaches to create a more equitable world while also solving critical global challenges. The hope is to align incentives allowing economic needs to bring about flourishing for the entrepreneurs, their communities and the planet. This framework has been supported and promoted by the UN, the World Bank and other multinational NGOs. 
The aim to create a triple bottom line, aligning people, profit and the planet is admirable. A challenge emerges when those most capable to contribute to their communities through their social entrepreneurial activities, an act I call social entrepreneurial placemaking, leave in times of crisis.
Over the course of 2020, Beirut faced an economic collapse, failed protest movement, a pandemic, as well as an acute stressor in the form of a major explosion which destroyed large sections of the capital. We were running a social entrepreneurship training program and collecting psychometric and qualitative data over the course of this time period and this research aims to assess migration ideation, placemaking ideation and the factors which influence how people respond. ","uid":"2LJlXk3rp","edit-time":1622099264563},{"string":"Entrepreneurship ","uid":"SGPCNwaoi","create-time":1622795199316,"edit-time":1622795204255,":create/user":{":user/uid":"OExdZZP8Xgdv4n4JK3xiq0GWER22"},":edit/user":{":user/uid":"OExdZZP8Xgdv4n4JK3xiq0GWER22"}}],"refs":[{"uid":"i3miylyML"}],"string":"Introduction:: ","uid":"4N-nVyk1R","create-time":1622099264553,"edit-time":1622099264553,":block/refs":[{":block/uid":"i3miylyML"}]},{"children":[{"string":"We conducted qualitative semi-structured interviews a few months after the blast. Our approach was to use a grounded theory approach to identify supports for entrepreneurial placemaking, deliberation methods, feelings, and ways of responding to the blast while also gathering measures to be able to classify and cluster the interviews. We then took this data and created visual representations using a graph-based clustering and other data-visualization methods to identify important clustering factors. 
The measures we assessed we're the Post Traumatic Growth Index (PTGI Tedeschi & Calhoun 1996), the Resilience Coping Scale (BRCS Sinclair and Wallson 2004), Impact of Event Scale: Revised (IES-R DS Weiss 2007), VIA Inventory of Strengths (VIA-IS Peterson & Seligman 2004) and the Intrusive - Event Related Rumination Inventory (EERI Cann et al., 2011). I think I lived through different experiences to help me reach where I am and I'm looking for more experiences to help me understand [[Code: Value-Self knowledge]]"who is [participants name referenced I worked with different non-profits that helped me, and I went to them for help because yeah, I want to be an entrepreneur although I don't have the full set of skills that I need. I worked with a different number of them. One of the things that made me more passionate for education was a program with Teach For Lebanon, it's a program a part of a global program called Teach for All.  You go and work in an underprivileged school and you learn about how the kids are suffering and you learn about so many eye opening things.
