Pbos genomesequencing project hopes to point up the differences that enabled humans unlike the Neanderthals with...](https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5909685dc14b3c606c106cd2/master/w_2560%2Cc_limit/110815_r21179_g2048.jpg)____Svante Pääbo’s genome-sequencing project hopes to point up the differences that enabled humans, unlike the Neanderthals, with whom they interbred, to build complex societies.__Art by ATELIER DAYNÈS; PHOTOGRAPH: S. ENTRESSANGLE__","uid":"o-L-wu8pb","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"The Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology, in Leipzig, is a large, mostly glass building shaped a bit like a banana. The institute sits at the southern edge of the city, in a neighborhood that still very much bears the stamp of its East German past. If you walk down the street in one direction, you come to a block of Soviet-style apartment buildings; in the other, to a huge hall with a golden steeple, which used to be known as the Soviet Pavilion. (The pavilion is now empty.) In the lobby of the institute there’s a cafeteria and an exhibit on great apes. A TV in the cafeteria plays a live feed of the orangutans at the Leipzig Zoo.","uid":"B2-V10c0R","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"Svante Pääbo heads the institute’s department of evolutionary genetics. He is tall and lanky, with a long face, a narrow chin, and bushy eyebrows, which he often raises to emphasize some sort of irony. Pääbo’s office is dominated by a life-size model of a Neanderthal skeleton, propped up so that its feet dangle over the floor, and by a larger-than-life-size portrait that his graduate students presented to him on his fiftieth birthday. Each of the students painted a piece of the portrait, the over-all effect of which is a surprisingly good likeness of Pääbo, but in mismatched colors that make it look as if he had a skin disease.","uid":"4TW8XKTVG","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"At any given moment, Pääbo has at least half a dozen research efforts in progress. When I visited him in May, he had one team analyzing DNA that had been obtained from a forty- or fifty-thousand-year-old finger bone found in Siberia, and another trying to extract DNA from a cache of equally ancient bones from China. A third team was slicing open the brains of mice that had been genetically engineered to produce a human protein.","uid":"5atdRpp2T","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"In Pääbo’s mind, at least, these research efforts all hang together. They are attempts to solve a single problem in evolutionary genetics, which might, rather dizzyingly, be posed as: What made us the sort of animal that could create a transgenic mouse?","uid":"EIEmVcILt","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"The question of what defines the human has, of course, been kicking around since Socrates, and probably a lot longer. If it has yet to be satisfactorily resolved, then this, Pääbo suspects, is because it has never been properly framed. “The challenge is to address the questions that are answerable,” he told me.","uid":"6uG5baoXt","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"Pääbo’s most ambitious project to date, which he has assembled an international consortium to assist him with, is an attempt to sequence the entire genome of the Neanderthal. The project is about halfway complete and has already yielded some unsettling results, including the news, announced by Pääbo last year, that modern humans, before doing in the Neanderthals, must have interbred with them.","uid":"vwZAiLNse","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"Once the Neanderthal genome is complete, scientists will be able to lay it gene by gene—indeed, base by base—against the human, and see where they diverge. At that point, Pääbo believes, an answer to the age-old question will finally be at hand. Neanderthals were very closely related to modern humans—so closely that we shared our prehistoric beds with them—and yet clearly they were __not__ humans. Somewhere among the genetic disparities must lie the mutation or, more probably, mutations that define us. Pääbo already has a team scanning the two genomes, drawing up lists of likely candidates.","uid":"mOfvHwyxA","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"“I want to know what changed in fully modern humans, compared with Neanderthals, that made a difference,” he said. “What made it possible for us to build up these enormous societies, and spread around the globe, and develop the technology that I think no one can doubt is unique to humans. There has to be a genetic basis for that, and it is hiding somewhere in these lists.”","uid":"bg-dwIpDF","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"Pääbo, who is now fifty-six, grew up in Stockholm. His mother, a chemist, was an Estonian refugee. For a time, she worked in the laboratory of a biochemist named Sune Bergström, who later won a Nobel Prize. Pääbo was the product of a lab affair between the two, and, although he knew who his father was, he wasn’t supposed to discuss it. Bergström had a wife and another son; Pääbo’s mother, meanwhile, never married. Every Saturday, Bergström would visit Pääbo and take him for a walk in the woods, or somewhere else where he didn’t think he’d be recognized.","uid":"Bo4QVl-Xr","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"“Officially, at home, he worked on Saturday,” Pääbo told me. “It was really crazy. His wife knew. But they never talked about it. She never tried to call him at work on Saturdays.” As a child, Pääbo wasn’t particularly bothered by the whole arrangement; later, he occasionally threatened to knock on Bergström’s door. “I would say, ‘You have to tell your son—your other son—because he will find out sometime,’ ” he recalled. Bergström would promise to do this, but never followed through. (As a result, Bergström’s other son did not learn that Pääbo existed until shortly before Bergström’s death, in 2004.)","uid":"hr-P2_v3o","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"VIDEO FROM THE NEW YORKER","uid":"CvosmeJfQ","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"[A Street Musician Fights the Stigma of Albinism in Africa](https://www.newyorker.com/video/watch/the-new-yorker-documentary-lazarus)","uid":"-TQc4HQBJ","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"From an early age, Pääbo was interested in old things. He discovered that around fallen trees it was sometimes possible to find bits of pottery made by prehistoric Swedes, and he filled his room with potsherds. When he was a teen-ager, his mother took him to visit the Pyramids, and he was entranced. He enrolled at Uppsala University, planning to become an Egyptologist.","uid":"ZZWuTLwPk","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"“I really wanted to discover mummies, like Indiana Jones,” he said. Mostly, though, the coursework turned out to involve parsing hieroglyphics, and instead of finding it swashbuckling Pääbo thought it was boring. Inspired by his father, he switched first to medicine, then to cell biology.","uid":"Eh9HdsE3x","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"In the early nineteen-eighties, Pääbo was doing doctoral research on viruses when he once again began fantasizing about mummies. At least as far as he could tell, no one had ever tried to obtain DNA from an ancient corpse. It occurred to him that if this was possible, then a whole new way of studying history would open up.","uid":"hjfevMYOJ","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"Suspecting that his dissertation adviser would find the idea silly (or worse), Pääbo conducted his mummy research in secret, at night. With the help of one of his former Egyptology professors, he managed to obtain some samples from the Egyptian Museum in what was then East Berlin. In 1984, he published his results in an obscure East German journal. He had, he wrote, been able to detect DNA in the cells of a mummified child who’d been dead for more than two thousand years. Among the questions that Pääbo thought mummy DNA could answer were what caused pharaonic dynasties to change and who Tutankhamun’s mom was.","uid":"v9APhnaQv","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"While Pääbo was preparing a version of his mummy paper for publication in English, a group of scientists from the University of California at Berkeley announced that they had succeeded in sequencing a snippet of DNA from a zebralike animal known as a quagga, which had been hunted to extinction in the eighteen-eighties. (The DNA came from a hundred-and-forty-year-old quagga hide preserved at the National History Museum in Mainz.) The leader of the team, Allan Wilson, was an eminent biochemist who had, among other things, come up with a way to study evolution using the concept of a “molecular clock.” Pääbo sent Wilson the galleys of his mummy paper. Impressed, Wilson replied asking if there was any space in Pääbo’s lab; he might like to spend a sabbatical there. Pääbo had to write back that he could not offer Wilson space in his lab, because, regrettably, he didn’t have a lab—or even, at that point, a Ph.D.","uid":"ToCefpvOz","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"Pääbo’s mummy paper became the cover article in __Nature.__ It was also written up in the __Times__, which called his achievement “the most dramatic of a series of recent accomplishments using molecular biology.” Pääbo’s colleagues in Sweden, though, remained skeptical. They urged him to forget about shrivelled corpses and stick to viruses.","uid":"sWZhAah2U","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"“Everybody told me that it was really stupid to leave that important area for something which looked like a hobby of some sort,” he said. Ignoring them, Pääbo moved to Berkeley, to work for Wilson.","uid":"rygRKlbNq","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"“He just kind of glided in,” Mary-Claire King, who had also been a student of Wilson’s, and who is now a professor of genome sciences at the University of Washington, recalled. According to King, Pääbo and Wilson, who died in 1991, turned out to share much more than an interest in ancient DNA.","uid":"NOWwz_mgs","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"“Each of them thought of very big ideas,” she told me. “And each of them was very good at translating those ideas into testable hypotheses. And then each of them was very good at developing the technology that’s necessary to test the hypotheses. And to have all three of those capacities is really remarkable.” Also, although “they were both very data-driven, neither was afraid to say outrageous things about their data, and neither was afraid to be wrong.”","uid":"AsHrFQKr_","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"DNA is often compared to a text, a comparison that’s apt as long as the definition of “text” encompasses writing that doesn’t make sense. DNA consists of molecules known as nucleotides knit together in the shape of a ladder—the famous double helix. Each nucleotide contains one of four bases: adenine, thymine, guanine, and cytosine, which are designated by the letters A, T, G, and C, so that a stretch of the human genome might be represented as ACCTCCTCTAATGTCA. (This is an actual sequence, from chromosome 10; the comparable sequence in an elephant is ACCTCCCCTAATGTCA.) The human genome is three billion bases—or, really, base pairs—long. As far as can be determined, most of it is junk.","uid":"6QfD2gcmk","edit-time":1622797316989},{"children":[{"string":"[🔗](https://www.facebook.com/dialog/feed?&display=popup&caption=&app_id=1147169538698836&link=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fcartoon%2Fa15905%3Futm_source%3Dfacebook%26utm_medium%3Dsocial%26utm_campaign%3Donsite-share%26utm_brand%3Dthe-new-yorker%26utm_social-type%3Dearned)","uid":"H1EXHLNqD","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"[🔗](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fcartoon%2Fa15905%3Futm_source%3Dtwitter%26utm_medium%3Dsocial%26utm_campaign%3Donsite-share%26utm_brand%3Dthe-new-yorker%26utm_social-type%3Dearned&text=&via=NewYorker)","uid":"cp3UOAuRU","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"[🔗](mailto:?subject=&body=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fcartoon%2Fa15905%3Futm_source%3Donsite-share%26utm_medium%3Demail%26utm_campaign%3Donsite-share%26utm_brand%3Dthe-new-yorker)","uid":"auN7jV3hh","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"[🔗](https://condenaststore.com/conde-nast-brand/cartoons)","uid":"OZvDDLr2s","edit-time":1622797316989}],"string":"![Your mother and I are separating because I want whats best for the country and your mother doesnt.](https://media.newyorker.com/cartoons/593b61498a032b339a0cd2e2/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/110815_a15905_g2048.jpg)[🔗](https://www.newyorker.com/cartoon/a15905)____“Your mother and I are separating because I want what’s best for the country and your mother doesn’t.”____","uid":"MF2ifGYX-","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"With the exception of red blood cells, every cell in an organism contains a complete copy of its DNA. It also contains many copies—hundreds to thousands—of an abridged form of DNA known as mitochondrial DNA, or mtDNA. But as soon as the organism dies the long chains of nucleotides begin to break down. Much of the damage is done in the first few hours, by enzymes inside the creature’s own body. After a while, all that remains is snippets, and after a longer while—how long seems to depend on the conditions of decomposition—these snippets, too, disintegrate. “Maybe in the permafrost you could go back five hundred thousand years,” Pääbo told me. “But it’s certainly on this side of a million.” Five hundred thousand years ago, the dinosaurs had been dead for more than sixty-four million years, so the whole “Jurassic Park” fantasy is, sadly, just that. On the other hand, five hundred thousand years ago modern humans did not yet exist.","uid":"L99gPqDL0","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"When Pääbo arrived in California, he was still interested in finding a way to use genetics to study human history. He’d discovered, however, a big problem with trying to locate fragments of ancient Egyptian DNA: they look an awful lot like—indeed, identical to—fragments of contemporary human DNA. Thus a single microscopic particle of his own skin, or of someone else’s, even some long-dead museum curator’s, could nullify months of work.","uid":"qN-ie8kex","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"“It became clear that human contamination was a huge problem,” he explained. (Eventually, Pääbo concluded that the sequences he had obtained for his original mummy paper had probably been corrupted in this way.) As a sort of warmup exercise, he began working on extinct animals. He analyzed scraps of mtDNA from giant ground sloths, which disappeared about twelve thousand years ago, and from mammoths, which vanished around the same time, and from Tasmanian tigers, which were hunted to extinction by the nineteen-thirties. He extracted mtDNA from moas, the giant flightless birds that populated New Zealand before the arrival of the Maori, and found that moas were more closely related to birds from Australia than to kiwis, the flightless birds that inhabit New Zealand today. “That was a blow to New Zealand self-esteem,” he recalled. He also probed plenty of remains that yielded no usable DNA, including bones from the La Brea tar pits and fossilized insects preserved in amber. In the process of this work, Pääbo more or less invented the field of paleogenetics.","uid":"C84buRVia","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"ADVERTISEMENT","uid":"ea6DWuOyQ","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"“Frankly, it was a problem that I wouldn’t have tackled myself, because I thought it was too difficult,” Maynard Olson, an emeritus professor at the University of Washington and one of the founders of the Human Genome Project, told me. “Pääbo brought very high standards to this area, and took the field of ancient DNA study from its ‘Jurassic Park’ origins to a real science, which is a major accomplishment.”","uid":"PXCJxznUC","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"“There’s nothing unique about most of science,” Ed Green, a professor of biomolecular engineering at the University of California at Santa Cruz who works on the Neanderthal Genome Project, said. “If you don’t do it, somebody else is going to do it a few months later. Svante is one of the rare people in science for whom that is not true. There wouldn’t even be a field of ancient DNA as we know it without him.”","uid":"vw9pGDTCt","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"“It’s a nice rarity in science when people take not only unique but also productive paths,” Craig Venter, who led a rival effort to the Human Genome Project, told me. “And Svante has clearly done both. I have immense respect for him and what he’s done.”","uid":"JcIFGXPuF","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"While Pääbo was living in California, he sometimes went to Germany to visit a woman who was attending graduate school at the University of Munich. “I had many relationships with men, but I also had girlfriends now and again,” he told me. The relationship ended; shortly afterward, the University of Munich offered Pääbo an assistant professorship. With no pressing reason to move to Germany, he demurred. The offer was increased to a full professorship: “So then I said, ‘Germany isn’t that bad after all. I’ll go there for a few years.’ ”","uid":"62OAYjfTD","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"Pääbo was still in Munich several years later when he got a call from the Rhenish State Museum, in Bonn. The museum houses the bones of the first Neanderthal to be identified as such, which was discovered in the summer of 1856. What did Pääbo think the odds were that he could extract usable DNA? He had no way of determining what kind of shape the bones were in until he dissolved them.","uid":"Bo52jibTC","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"“I didn’t know what to tell them, so I said, ‘There’s a five-per-cent chance that it works,’ ” he recalled. A few months later, he received a small chunk of the Neanderthal’s right humerus.","uid":"WxXMpSTc8","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"The first Neanderthal was found in a limestone cave about forty-five miles north of Bonn, in an area known as the Neander Valley, or, in German, __das Neandertal.__ Although the cave is gone—the limestone was long ago quarried into building blocks—the area is now a sort of Neanderthal theme park, with its own museum, hiking trails, and a garden planted with the kinds of shrubs that would have been encountered during an ice age. In the museum, Neanderthals are portrayed as kindly, if not particularly telegenic, humans. By the entrance to the building, there’s a model of an elderly Neanderthal leaning on a stick. He is smiling benignantly and resembles an unkempt Yogi Berra. Next to him is one of the museum’s most popular attractions—a booth called the Morphing-Station. For three euros, visitors to the station can get a normal profile shot of themselves and, facing that, a second shot that has been doctored. In the second, the chin recedes, the forehead slopes, and the back of the head bulges out. Kids love to see themselves—or, better yet, their siblings—morphed into Neanderthals. They find it screamingly funny.","uid":"mOV-ZVHby","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"When the first Neanderthal bones showed up in the Neander Valley, they were treated as rubbish (and almost certainly damaged in the process). The fragments—a skullcap, four arm bones, two thighbones, and part of a pelvis—were later salvaged by a local businessman, who, thinking they belonged to a cave bear, passed them on to a fossil collector. The fossil collector realized that he was dealing with something much stranger than a bear. He declared the remains to be traces of a “primitive member of our race.”","uid":"wATXibg4X","edit-time":1622797316989},{"string":"As it happened, this was right around the time that Darwin published “On the Origin of Species,” and the fragments soon got caught up in the debate over the origin of humans. Opponents of evolution insisted that they belonged to an ordinary person. One theory held that it was a Cossack who had wandered into the region in the tumult following the Napoleonic Wars. The reason the bones looked odd—Neanderthal femurs are distinctly bowed—was that the Cossack had spent too long on his horse. Another attributed the remains to a man with rickets: the man had been in so much pain from his disease that he’d kept his forehead perpetually tensed—hence the protruding brow ridge. (What a man with rickets and in constant pain was doing climbing into a cave was never

messages.content:
Based on your responses, it seems that the most promising directions for your paper revolve around the themes of spirituality, deliberate rumination, values/character strengths, and social connection as key factors supporting entrepreneurial resilience and growth in challenging contexts. Here are three potential paper concepts that aim to capture these core insights while highlighting the unique contributions of your research:

Title 1: The Alchemy of Adversity: How Spirituality and Deliberate Rumination Foster Post-Traumatic Growth in Social Entrepreneurs

Subtitle: Insights from a Character Strengths Analysis of Lebanese Entrepreneurs Navigating Crisis

Introduction:
This paper explores the critical role of spirituality and deliberate rumination in promoting post-traumatic growth among social entrepreneurs in Lebanon, drawing on a mixed-methods study conducted before and after the Beirut Port explosion of 2020. Combining qualitative interviews with a pre-post analysis of entrepreneur character strengths, the findings underscore the importance of cultivating a sense of meaning and engaging in purposeful reflection to alchemize adversity into growth. The paper argues for the integration of spiritual practices and structured opportunities for deliberate rumination into entrepreneurship education and support programs, particularly in contexts of crisis and uncertainty. Theoretical and practical implications for fostering entrepreneurial resilience and social impact are discussed.

Conclusion:
The insights from this study suggest that spirituality and deliberate rumination are potent catalysts for post-traumatic growth among social entrepreneurs navigating contexts of crisis and uncertainty. By providing a framework for meaning-making and purposeful reflection on challenges, these practices can help entrepreneurs alchemize adversity into growth and renewed commitment to social impact. This research calls for a paradigm shift in entrepreneurship education and support programs, one that integrates spiritual development and structured opportunities for deliberate rumination alongside traditional skills training. Such a holistic approach to cultivating entrepreneurial resilience has the potential to transform not only individual founders, but also the communities they serve. Further research is needed to explore the specific mechanisms through which spirituality and deliberate rumination foster growth, as well as to develop and test interventions that effectively integrate these practices into entrepreneur support systems.

Title 2: Values in Action: Cultivating Character Strengths for Entrepreneurial Resilience and Prosocial Impact 

Subtitle: A Mixed-Methods Study of Lebanese Social Entrepreneurs Navigating the Beirut Port Explosion

Introduction:
This paper investigates the role of character strengths in promoting entrepreneurial resilience and prosocial impact among social entrepreneurs in Lebanon navigating the aftermath of the Beirut Port explosion of 2020. Through a mixed-methods approach combining pre-post character strengths assessments with qualitative interviews, the study identifies key strengths such as spirituality, teamwork, and leadership that were associated with entrepreneurs' ability to persist and even grow through crisis. The findings underscore the importance of cultivating a values-driven approach to entrepreneurship education and support, one that helps founders leverage their unique strengths to navigate challenges and create positive social change. Implications for the design and implementation of character-based interventions in entrepreneurship programs are discussed, particularly in contexts of adversity and uncertainty.

Conclusion: 
The results of this mixed-methods study highlight the vital role of character strengths in fostering entrepreneurial resilience and prosocial impact in the face of crisis and uncertainty. By identifying key strengths such as spirituality, teamwork, and leadership that were associated with entrepreneurs' ability to persist and grow through the aftermath of the Beirut Port explosion, this research provides a foundation for the development of values-driven approaches to entrepreneurship education and support. Such approaches would help founders cultivate and leverage their unique character strengths to navigate challenges and create positive social change, transforming adversity into opportunities for growth and impact. This study calls for further research to explore the mechanisms through which specific character strengths promote resilience and prosocial behavior, as well as to design and evaluate character-based interventions that can be integrated into entrepreneurship programs in contexts of crisis and uncertainty. Ultimately, by empowering entrepreneurs to lead with their values and strengths, we can foster a more resilient and impactful startup ecosystem globally.

Title 3: Stronger Together: The Power of Social Connection and Deliberate Rumination in Cultivating Entrepreneurial Resilience

Subtitle: Lessons from Lebanese Social Entrepreneurs in the Aftermath of the Beirut Port Explosion

Introduction:
This paper explores the critical role of social connection and deliberate rumination in promoting resilience among social entrepreneurs navigating the aftermath of the Beirut Port explosion of 2020. Drawing on qualitative interviews with Lebanese entrepreneurs, the findings highlight the transformative power of strong relationships and purposeful reflection in helping founders persist and even grow through crisis. The paper argues for the intentional cultivation of supportive entrepreneurial communities and structured opportunities for deliberate rumination within entrepreneurship education and support programs, particularly in contexts of adversity and uncertainty. Strategies for fostering social connection and reflective practice are discussed, along with implications for entrepreneurship research and practice in an increasingly volatile world.

Conclusion:
The insights from this qualitative study underscore the vital role of social connection and deliberate rumination in cultivating entrepreneurial resilience in the face of crisis and uncertainty. By providing a supportive community and opportunities for purposeful reflection, entrepreneurship education and support programs can help founders weather challenges and even transform adversity into growth. This research calls for a shift towards more relationally and reflectively oriented approaches to entrepreneurship development, particularly in contexts of volatility and disruption. Further research is needed to explore the specific mechanisms through which social connection and deliberate rumination foster resilience, as well as to develop and test interventions that effectively integrate these practices into entrepreneur support systems. Ultimately, by empowering entrepreneurs to build strong relationships and engage in transformative reflection, we can cultivate a more resilient and interconnected startup ecosystem that is better equipped to navigate the challenges of an increasingly uncertain world.

These paper concepts aim to capture the essence of your unique research insights while situating them within the broader context of entrepreneurial resilience, post-traumatic growth, and social impact. By highlighting the transformative power of spirituality, character strengths, social connection, and deliberate rumination, these papers offer a fresh perspective on how to cultivate more resilient and values-driven entrepreneurs in an age of uncertainty. The goal is to inspire further research and practical applications that empower founders to navigate adversity with grace, wisdom, and a steadfast commitment to positive change.

Thesis: Post Traumatic Growth, Character Strengths, Humor, Deliberate Rumination, Social Support and Entrepreneurial Training Programs as Presilience Training - Summary of Ideas
The following interviews were conducted and tagged by Bilal Ghalib, co-founder of Bloom.pm, and Masters Student at the Learning Planet Institute in 2021. Bilal had run an entrepreneurial acceleration program for social impact entrepreneurs in Lebanon which happened to overlap with COVID, the start of the economic collapse and protest movements, as well as an enormous blast called the Beirut Port Explosion that destroyed many homes, buildings, offices, businesses and killed many people. Many of the participants were impacted physically and all impacted mentally. The research used a mixed methods approach focusing on the tool that was used prior to the blast to assess their VIA score (values in action characters profile from the school of positive psychology) it has been shown that the Flourishing measure and higher scores on VIA are correlated, thus we take this measure as a proxy for wellbeing. We also note individual factors like humor, teamwork, leadership and others seem to buffer participants from the negative impacts of the Blast. Our research attempts to identify factors that correlate with post traumatic growth as we witnessed that most of the participants that went through our program returned to their baseline VIA wellbeing proxy faster than those who only attended a two week program where we were able to assess them, and then we asked them to return for an assessment at the same time as when we assessed people that went through both the 2 week program and the 3 month program. We believe we identified something in the 3 month program that we’d like to isolate and theorize the operations of systematically to develop a framework and impleemntation suggestions for other programs, educational and in business, to support the development of “pre-resillience” aka: presilience.

Can you tell me a little about what has been supporting you personally and professionally since the blast?
What role do you see entrepreneurs having in a place like Lebanon given the current situation?
Who were you able to speak to about your experience?
I’m very open with everyone, with my employees I’m very close to them. Software engineers are like computers, I can talk to them but they don’t talk back. I’m never only talking about myself. I normalize talking about emotions so they’re encouraged to share with me.[[Code: Altruism]] No matter what encounter I want to leave something with each person I meet. That someone might remember this conversation and perhaps think in a new way.
Talking to people is no longer bound to my physical constraints so I’m talking to many more people these days. I have different communities I talk to. I go and round up people to talk to their different communities and find myself talking to a group of 40 people inspiring them. Aye, kthier.
What did the accelerator mean during the blast period?
I still remember, noticing, during the weekly check ins - I was having a rough period in my life in June/July before the blast. I was done with school, I had graduated and there was hyperinflation. I felt I had to get a job to help the family sustain. I was actively looking and feeling panic and we were as a family operating on savings. My dad was telling me that my retirement was less than 10,000 dollars, imagine that. [[Code: Financial]] So it was crazy. I noticed I’m using the word “Frustrated a lot” - Munir mentioned that I was “frustrated a lot” and it stood out to me. I realized that being frustrated is not productive while you’re in a startup because you need to be innovative and creative and being frustrated doesn’t help you come up with new ideas. [[Code: Value-Self knowledge]] I got this thing with berrytech and finally I relaxed. [[Code: Safety]]
1
All the calls were really so helpful. Not everyone was on the calls all the time, we wanted everyone to be there! People have lives and you can’t force people to always join. I’m the kind of person who always comes up with ideas in conversation. I was talking with my designer and had an idea, started sketching and it was an unannounced brainstorming session. [[Code: Social-Support]][[Code: Value-Creativity]]. We sketched almost half of the book. Talking out loud you get more ideas.
You were there for us, and the cash support really helped a lot. The cash support, before leaving my job, the money I received from you had just finished and then I got the job. So September was covered and it was such good timing. My contract ends in June with Berrytech and I am very confident that I will get another opportunity somewhere else. I’ve been doing a lot of good [[Code: Personality Trait]]
What role do you see entrepreneurs having in a place like Lebanon given the current situation?
I strongly believe that entrepreneurs will save the region. We’re non-partisan, non-political, we’re grassroots, we’re in pain and from the pain we’re trying to do good and create products. I’m very proud of all the people working in startups, especially the people empowering people, teaching people how to think, sharing new skills. Everything involving human development is multiplied by 2000% because that’s someone doing something new and it has a ripple effect. When you empower a person you empower many more indirectly. Entities like Nawaya, Enjaz, Dot, who are getting money from outside, empowering people to start coming up with projects and I’m very happy with the sessions they give. I start telling them - I know the situation is hard, you need to make money, dollars, not Lebanese. The country has a lot of raw materials, but our minds are not industrial, when you think about how much goodness is in the country. As simple as flowers, honey, how can we innovate? The plentitude of potatoes in Bekaa? Create a market for you. Make the spoons from honey, it’s very nice. I buy it because we can, companies are making money. WHat can we invent. Create new products from the earth, learn e-commerce, we’re teaching you ecommerce. Learn the tools, it’s for free. As much as I can I’m trying to share this. Don’t make the same product and sell it in the same village. In Beirut no one makes authentic “mooneh” - we look for the people who do? There’s lots of people like me and expats who’re looking for Lebanese products, the smell of the region. [[Code: Expat-support]] The entities are teaching the skills they need to transform the resources around them into products. And this is how we will emerge from our problem, it’s industrialization and creating products. [[Code: Vision]]
1
What do you say the people leaving?
I won't lie, sometimes I feel like leaving too. Why do I think about it? To keep this engine/enthusiasm/giving to people I have to feel secure[[Code: Feeling-Fear]]. Not that I will die at any instant. So much is online so I can do so much of my work online. I can be effective even if I’m not physically in the country. I think of my safety, my family… and my earnings. Now I’m fine. After a while will I still be fine? I’m investing from my income, will I still be able to invest in my team? That’s the one thing I’m thinking about. [[Code: Feeling-secure]] [[Code: Feeling-Gratitude]] I’m investing in the base, raising this “child” so that one day the company will come and pay me back and take care of me when I’m older. Regardless of what happens to me, I believe I can control my reaction to it.
I don't perceive things bad/right. I don't overreact to things. I take things neutrally. I take some time to assess the feeling / incident I am in. It will take a few mins. I recall often that I tell people that I will get back to them after 5-10 mins. I ask "What do you mean about it" I don't open much room for misunderstanding. In what sense did you mean that? Not an easily provoked person. [[Code: Value-Self knowledge]]
Where did you develop this skill?
Arts taught me a lot. Being objective. I lived in this culture taboos - I always share this example. We used to draw nudes. We were very objective about it regardless of what it has inside it. Definitely connected with meditation [[Code: Coping-Meditation]], I deal with people the same way I deal with my thoughts. Zen books, mindfulness books and would read 15/16. Just jumping into technology and school. I had an iPod touch we did a lot of things on it. I always searched for ways to calm my mind. I had struggles when I was a kid. Didn't have a perfect childhood (no childhood actually). Searched for things that can help calm my mind. my brother was abroad and asked for xyz book and he brought them with him. [[Code: Experience-Prior-Violence]] Developed meditation with time - took me 4 years (till 20) till i can fall deeply into a meditative state. 15 year old, no support. 12-15 black hole from this time. When I finally got out of depression, I immediately became a semi mature person for 15 years old. I just started therepy 1 month ago. I believe there are still things in childhood I need to discover and I need the support of someone else. I don't tell people about it, it's still a taboo to talk about it. I get the guidance that I need. If I don't invest in myself there's nothing more worthy. When I was financially strong enough to invest in myself it was the most important thing I could do. With being a human we have a lot of complexity. And when I see that I'm questioning purpose I know I need some help. [[Code: Value-Self-care]]  [[Code: Therapy]] [[Code: Coping]]

One of the things that supported me is that by being working on multiple things kept me busy from really thinking about what happened [[Code: Response-Avoidance]] [[Code: Response-Overworking]]
What role do you see entrepreneurs having in a place like Lebanon given the current situation?
Entrepreneurs I think are the main part of getting the situation better. The large companies we are used for are mostly owned by the corrupted political people. [[Code: Feeling-Anger Corruption]]
For this reason there is a need for the entrepreneurs to be creating alternatives for these companies. But another point that many entrepreneurs think about their start-ups will make them the next billionaire which is leading them to move their start-ups outside the country where there is a more stable situation [[Code: Response-Migration Ideation]] Additionally, there is a need to focus on the Social Entrepreneurship that will add an impact to the society while still staying sustainable

How do you feel when you're 89
I'm shredded, I'm muscular. Something in your head gives you confidence or rips it off. Entrepreneurship training. Basically the most important thing is consistency. No matter if you're motivated or not, see the end of the tunnel or not. If you're self disciplined and consistent will hold you till you get to the breakthrough.
How are things for you this week?
I flooded myself with work. Being in my bubble and doing good things. Being productive, being able to contribute to projects. Self fulfilling. I can waste as much time as I want. I have lots of projects that I've been approached with many. projects I'm jumping two feet in - especially entrepreneurship and helping startups get their things right and get their products. I wasn't fooled. General knowledge of things isn't always the best way to do it. Ecommerce - very efficient. Taking a lot of projects, consulting with ITC people, women led businesses. [[Concluding Statements]][[008 Interview]]
Can you tell me a little about what has been supporting you personally and professionally since the blast?
What role do you see entrepreneurs having in a place like Lebanon given the current situation?
The experienced ones have a duty to cultivate young entrepreneurs.[[Code: Altruism]] At 35 I can still have a good amount of energy. Younger ones that are 20-23 - fresh out of UNI that have literally no idea what's happening outside. They either get stuck in a job that they don't like. Get suicidal thoughts or want to leave. Entrepreneur to be able to start a company to have employees to grow economically has to have discipline / Faith. The ones that have experience would rather go to another country. If you want to keep the brain drain.... to keep them here you have to advise/lead/to give the best of your knowledge to help them create something that is sustainable. It's not easy. Huge skillset, highly employable. For a fresh grad. They need people to genuinely want them to stay in the country. to help them be sustainable, create a job/ a business. A moral duty. Believe it or not. I advise more than 30 startups, all of them are young kids. I do this out of purpose. It gives me fulfillment to be honest with you. [[Code: Altruism]]I didn't make it at their age. They need incentives, cash in their hands. They shouldn't be worried about their livelihood - bread for their family at the end of the day, Less damaging. I'm here because my parents are old, I'm the one they rely on.[[Code: Family-Responsibility]] Even if it's on my own expenses and the life i'm longing to have with my future wife. I have my French tech visa, but I'm here. I'm here until things get better. I had people who I really appreciate who were pushing. Mentors, people I respect. Business people mostly. Mentoring/entrepreneurs. helped push you to get out of the grey zone. I was looking for an opportunity. Someone told me. Radical, straight to the point answers give you good material to reflect on. easier to take decisions

Can you tell me about your decision making process when you decided to start your own business?

2017 was a strange year, I wanted to work on my own projects. The "Real Deal" - ohhhh, where will it go. It was the year where nothing/everything really happened. I had a fight with my parents, left he house in an anger fit. It was an explosion of all the trauma that I lived as a child and I realized I didn't want to be a in that bubble anymore. And I was very keen I didn't want to work for someone else anymore. At that point in my life I felt I was working with the devil. All the people that I worked for were people trying to make more money unethically while I was living my worst days while they were supposed to be my best days. soooo - It was a moment where I realized. khalas. I can't find a way to put words on it. I've been recently thinking about how I got here (which is no where really) what are the events and what's the story. I have a hard time putting words on it. It's a part of my recovery and processing.

The programs and starting of projects requires money. If people with ideas don't get money the ideas will die. These challenges are punishment on the outside (zahir) and mercy on the inside (batin). We're going to reset our method of thinking. We used to have planting and manufacture. We had this mindset of buy complete and keep your money in the bank, that's all wrong. The crafts we've lost. The lands we've paved over for buildings. And now look all the buildings are closed. Where are the farmers? The money that we're getting from other countries, what's the point of it with the improper mindset of the Lebanese person who wants to buy cars. Let's hope that this countries people will wake up. I hope When the doors are closed the country requires its own investment in plants and manufacturing. [[Code: Feeling-Patriotism]]

Got some opportunities in different trainings. ACSI, all the mentorship/exposure network. Hearing experiences from different people. Everyone has something to add for you. All the things she's learned. Attending all the different training online. A Masters program, new course, new skills, new ideas. Meeting people online. Helped a lot [[Code: Spirituality]] [[Code: Religious-Prioritization]]

Rebuilding Lebanon. [[Code: Feeling-Hopeful]]

Solutions and garbage. Entrepreneurs do/think about it. Gender: Female

Family Description
Father was in love with business. He's an engineer. From the start he had a businesses in Saudi Arabia. He entered into banking, into shipments, so many different businesses. He was into medical supplies/real estate in the US. Construction material. 2011, Where can you imagine that he was in Africa one of the poorest countries. Niger. He was into creating a cementery there - he was 80 and it was a project that takes the design years. 10s of years to be created. [[Code: Background-Entrepreneurial Family]]
What are some of the things you feel you've learned from your father. I guess learning from failure and keep going always. [[Code: Learning-From Failure]]Just look at the future and possibilities. The one in Africa it was really something needed. Most of the businesses he did - like the shipment one, there was a war in Lebanon at the time - he created it to create businesses for my uncle at that time. [[Code: Background-Entrepreneurial Family]].
Do you think this way as well?
Sometimes yes, I have so many friends that are frustrated in their work, if I had my own I could work with them. I know them and I know what they are good at. That's one way the person can be good at. Unfortunately they're not working where they can be using their potential. [[Code: Social-Awareness]]
Are you using your potential these days?
I'm not good at being an employee, I have a focus problem one side, the other side it's related to the focus problem, I'm not fast. I keep reading, and rereading to check that I'm not making mistakes. I'm not a good employee and I'm more into managing something where I'm managing ideas It's not about being in a managerial - it's about being in a more creative and less administrative position. Where were you when the blast happened
Actually I was with a friend and we were in Hamra bringing something (he doesn't have a car) we just arrived - we were just next to the port - we went back to Hamra and he was taking stuff from his office. He was bringing stuff into his house. And it happened And he's close than me - in g3eitawi. [[Direct_Blast_Experience_True]]
What are your first memories of what happened then?
I found a place to hide, immediately, I just got - seated between two walls to protect myself and then came the second one. And my friend who was older than me, he was going to fall, because he was not hanging on anything. I pulled him in. - hamdullilah we were both ok. First thing I did was calling home. "how were people at home" [[Code: Family-Responsibility]] - they were under shock and they were ok, I'm in suyifi which was less damaged
Did you know people affected by the blast directly?
Yes, I know a lot of people. At the same moment I called people I know. I called a friend - in mar mkheil - hamdullilah she said they were ok. [[Code: Feeling-Gratitude]] He died a little while later. Something happened and they didn't know what. At MTV he was close, she got scratched all her body and face. And I know someone as well. Not so many people that I know. He was really old, not sure what conditions happened. Something entered into his head? Or the shock? He was already very old. It's very sad. I live with my mom/brotherWe are all affected, the situation of course. Because before that - the port - we already had the economic situation and we were feeling safe since a long time nothing happened security wise. we heard it could happen again. We don't feel safe anymore. [[Code: Feeling-Anxious]]
I don't have foreign nationality, decided not to take a French one. It's complicated to find a job, it's a safe thing to do to have a possibility if one has to go outside Lebanon. I would be interested in leaving if I had an opportunity.[[Code: Response-Migration Ideation]] someone said for Canada. Someone said it's very far and they don't take Lebanese for my age. For security reasons I could go to France for example. [[Code: Security]] It's a sure avenue, I need a challenge in my life. I don't like like routine.
Challenge to go to France? Would you be open to the challenge of building in Lebanon? Friend in France suggests to build a farm with chicken, it's very far from what I know from what I know and from another side I cannot kill animals. Growing your own food? [[Code: Response-Survivalist]] We will have to someday. These kinds of initiatives to feed yourself and others. One of the best shops in the neighborhood is someone taking a small place, taking a cheese and lebneh from the village. People are queuing a long time to have this.

Hamdullilah we didn't get hurt [[Code: Feeling-Gratitude]]- we think of all the victims of course.It could happen to anyone that could be there at the wrong time. Life, you lose something, win something else if you don't spend too much time looking at what you lost. I have a lot of negative people around me - my friends are always very negative around me. [[Code: Negative-Peer-Pressure]]
My friends are mostly negative. I need to find someone positive in my life. "why are you different than your friends" although sometimes I laugh, because they ask me for advice. I don't consider that I have a good career, they come to me for comfort because I think you can always at any age and any time create something from nothing if you have a good idea and are positive and consistent with it you will be successful. [[Code: Positivity]]
What encouragement would you give yourself?
so many things I want to do, I would organize myself in time slots and put everything in their own place and start something for my own and just keep going for it. - organize myself, even if it will be a total loss, it's something I will have to start.
How have you been coping after the blast?
First of all "time heals everything" [[Code: Adaptation]] so everyone got a little bit back to "normal" after some time. Of course being with your family you feel safe again, right?[[Code: Safety]] It gives you feeling that anything could happen at anytime life is short etc. being with your family and friends, you go back to "normal" - until now they keep fighting you in the media, they keep showing facts, they can't find the facts, there's other stuff in the port, and they bring back the fear, and they bring back the anger, [[Code: Reappraisal]] because they re-discuss this person bring it, this party, that party, they bring back the anger not knowing - they say it was potentially an intentional act. [[Code: Political Anger]]
Did you ever see/need to see a therepist?
No I didn't do. I'm one of the people who think it's a good idea to see a therapist. Especially the Lebanese have so many things going on. They go crazy they are just taking it on each other. They're shouting at each other.
what do you think about that what the media is doing?
It's useless, they are not serving us by doing this. [[Code: Feeling-Frustration]]They are producing anger that can't turn into anything. The people are already angry from the economic issue. They don't have proof. One can sit and do theories for hours. And media their role is to have proof and bring it to the people

Already now, and maybe more and more. Because people cannot get back to the people who are doing this to them. So they are doing it to each other.  [[Code: Feeling-Frustration]]
How do you see that in the street?
Any little thing they start a fight, small accident, super market, you can feel how nervous people. you can see in the faces people they are sad and angery.

[[History/Background]] [[018 Interview]]
Weekend Plans?
Iftar with my friends. Iftar - planning to go hiking. Didn't work. Weekend before is to go hiking. More of seeing friends / seeing nature when it works.
Easy to make time for nature?
There are weekends where I didn't feel they are weekends. If it's possible if I don't have tight deadlines. It becomes easy to unplug myself. If there are deadlines...
Last weekend - was good. I had a break, this weekend it might be hard because we have a pilot. We want to prepare for it. I like to have fast projects happening because there are a lot of interested people which is good. I see the company growing and it's' good. So it's not always negative to do that (work on the weekend).
Pilot with DOT. Teach students digital skills. They used to teach them, lots of organizations brought people to center and they - it's an opportunity for them to scale. If they can do it in a remote environment they might be able to handle 2x or 3x people to take advantage of the situation online. Used to do 30 students and now they want to do 100 students. I see the future more around blended learning.
Any time to relax on the weekend.
DOT - telegram group - we are trying to engage people in a group. Under research. To work with underserved communities. These people are left behind. The most impact can be. [[Code: Positive-Impact]]
Do you live with your family?
Can you tell me about your history with entrepreneurship?
First it started, as I remember. In grade. I wasn't sure how old I was - I started spending more time in the physics lab trying to understand how things work. I started exploring more of electronics and in grade 9 there was a competition to create a sort of project. A technology/innovation - I did something like a smart home. A lot of students do it. I wasn't aware of arduino, how to technically do that by taking an RC car/keyboard. Num lock light, sensor to trigger events from a program. This is how it started first.
At university I started the robotics club. At UNI - my roommate used to order stuff from AliExpress, if people would need any supplies they'd come to our dorm room(more like a maker space). After a while we thought more people in the university students that might be interested, we saw people come to our dorm room with interest so we thought we could start a club where we could build stuff together. We had to find 12 members and we gathered friends. Until now it's still running. It might be the first "Startup" I started
Stround	I used to do freelance development projects. A two person company - not "real UIUX" we were young, started from there. And after that for the final year project we applied for the SPEED Accelerator to fund (ProjectName)
I worked at Anghamy and Toters while in University. I was one of the first four developers. I was the IOs developer.I had some shares in Toters. But then when I went to (ProjectName) I returned everything back to focus on (ProjectName). I don't think my future is in a food app. I'm interested in building things and it's not my passion to work in food. So I took (ProjectName) to the SPEED accelerator. Through the robotics club we started teaching students robotics. Realized it could be done in a more interesting way. They were using the breadboard. The arduino is smart, the raspberry pi is smart, why isn't the breadboard smart? It's a valid and a very simple. Why doesn't it connect to your laptop... it's something we started on for our Final Year project, this is what we applied for in speed. These are the pins of the breadboard
Can you tell me about your decision making process when you decided to start your own business?
Can you tell me about how you got into Education.
To go back to school... I knew the education system is not good. I realized that schools didn't take into consideration what we are interested in, if I'm interested in this I'm going to spend time in this. And when I discovered this stuff my grades started getting lower but on the otherside I found something that was interesting for me. As we went through the acceleration program in SPEED, we were able to identify that this idea is not very doable. It needs a lot of... we have limitations on component sizes, we're using SMD/four layers/SMD sensors and everything, there's a limit to that. We're not able to do something something similar to the breadboard. The pin configurations will be different from that... so we zoomed out and thought, why are we doing this, to help students learn electronics - and what if the students were interested in different things? Also schools don't give them options to see / be exposed to new thing. how can we connect them to new learning opportunities that would be interesting for students. So we tried to alter the content to be more interesting for the students. We started zooming out step by step. We were trying to sell courses on ProjectName. We had a major problem. After ProjectName, our customers told us that they don't even have the ability to teach arabic/english how can you expect them to care about learning new things. There are a lot of marginalized people who aren't able to take advantage of online learning and there's a huge opportunity here
Working at Toters/Anghami what did you learn that might be helpful for your entrepreneurial journey.
Ay Anghami I was in touch with Eli Habib, the highest person/co-founder at the company. The work culture there I loved. The thing I learned is that a company doesn't have to be as boring as you think. Even if you are working you can even have fun/have friends. [[Code: Fun-at-work]] Anghami showed me the work culture, it surprised me; how can work culture be that fun. 2, when it comes to connection - the smallest person in the company can be connected to the co-founder - less hierarchy so it was interesting. At Toters, the founder was very focused on the numbers coming from a very big consulting firm. He was very precise and I liked that about him. Even if he spends the night at the office he had a very clear plan and was able to raise the amount he wanted to raise from investors and having a plan and following it strictly.

Bachelors in computer engineering

I felt like the medicine was controlling me. I felt like it might take me a logn time but i need to take control of my own life or else I will beon those meds forever. I wanted to be free. Till the school year ended I was going through the withdrawl phase - it was worse than depression, it was such a dark period. When the school year was coming to an end, I was telling the school thank you for the experience - that's it for me. I need something challenging, I need something where I feel like I am growing. I don't want to be like those teachers doing the same thing over and over for 20 years with 0 results. [[Code: Feeling-Frustration]]

We started Ringlet LMS before covid 19 for a reason, the reason was personalized education. To be able to easily track the data all the for each individual. Where were you when the blast happened
Saida
What are your first memories of what happened then?
It was really hard, we were in Saida and my house shook.  And I was like oh my god something's wrong - we have to check what's happening.We turned on the tv to check and it was an explosion in Beirut and my heart was broken. I started calling everyone in Beirut. Are you ok...
Then we created the group, we talked to my family/friends outside of lebanon, lots of people donated money. Lots of friends active in Beirut, one of the first things we did we started cleaning up. When I couldn't go - I donated money - only so much you can do. Beirut is not the same anymore, the energy is different.
Did you know people affected by the blast directly?
Yeah... definitely. I used to live in gemeyyze - my flatmates house was totally destroyed(thankfully they weren't there). Uncle/aunt in ABC and were thankfully ok. Some people I know got hurt. People who always stay at home, during the blast, and for some reason they weren't at home (do you think there's something to that?) [[Code: Spirituality]] [[Code: Feeling-Gratitude]] - I don't know, I don't like to assume / talk about the universe did something
What are some of the changes in your life since the August 4th blast?
I used to visit Beirut once a week, that would be my break. I' see my friends (most of my friends are in Beirut) - that stopped. hella I rarely visit beirut. That's leading to a lot of stress [[Code: Feeling-Fear]]- because I am not leaving saida. It's very small, I'm not connected here. Voluntarily. I choose not to have personal connections in this area.
I tried... Khalas, as long as I'm here, I think it's better - I'm the kind of person who's considreed different because I don't follow the crowd. [[Code: Contrarian-Thinking]]
I don't do what everyone else is doing just because everyone else is doing it. Here, most people chose to omit opinions/information. They decide to say it to other people and not you. I like being direct.
How did the blast affect your thinking?
Definitely we have a lot of unanswered questions - all of us. In Beirut or not. Sometimes it saddens me to see a friend who was in the Blast. Most of them are thinking differently "what do I have to lose"  - they lost something.
It's not the same with me because I wasn't there. - difference between what do I have to lose? - most of them are being irresponsible. [[Code: Response-Reckless-Behavior]]
I sit and I talk to them about it.
You need to sit with yourself and value yourself. When I said that I was on the way to doing something great. Bil 3ks, I redirected the traumatic event towards something better. [[Code: Silver-Linings]] [[Code: Feeling-Confidence]]
Maybe the level of intensity of my trauma, you deal with everything differently. 	The kind of trauma that they passed through was an instant, your life flashes in front of you. Mine was more of an experience and longer and more emotions there, so definitely different than the blast.
1
How did the blast affect your thinking/thinking about your projects?
No. If it has - definitely in a positive way. Not in a way that discouraged me. It opened my eyes on my target, where I should be focusing. We're focusing on the south region. [[Code: Silver-Linings]]
We have our connections barra and it's more difficult to connect to saudi, the market is bigger. "Why the south region" - because there's a very apparent gap, we have more than the LMS to put on the table, mindset skills, strategy, technique. Beirut already has the good consultants. The south is wallaashi(nothing) [[Code: Feeling-Compassion]][[Code: Feeling-Sad]]- you can get ahead - you can do so much better, just because you're not in Beirut you can still do better.
 Lot of schools in Beirut got destroyed in the blast, the whole city is broken. You feel it in the market. (sigh) [[Code: Feeling-Sad]] this is how I saw it, now I see that. I was targetting all over Lebanon. The nafseyyeh (attitude) in Beirut is different these days. i can't directly enter the market in Beirut without traction. In Saida I can get a client or two and be stronger before coming back to Beirut.
1
Any reminder brought back feelings about it
Because it was the place I used to go to relax, I don't feel like I can go back there whenever I want.
I had trouble staying asleep
I used to wake up and think... and think about Beirut. Inno beirut. Beirut was a person to me, not a place. I'd wake up and cry. It was really hard. [[Code: Feeling-Compassion]] What if it was a sister... a mother... someone you really knew. We're crying over people we never met in our entire lives. Everyone is connected in this country. We're all going through the same things no matter what. [[Code: Feeling-Patriotism]]
Other things kept making me think about it
Friends who was visiting at the time. We were having mcdonalds. All my friends are in Beirut. Anytime I'd visit my flatmate in Beirut. Oh my god! You know?
I felt irritable and angry
If I was there, definitely all the time. I don't want to underestimate what other people are feeling by saying all the time myself...
I avoided letting myself get upset when I thought about it or was reminded of it
I let myself feel everything. "did you have anything to help with those feelings" - not religious practices, spending time alone. [[Code: Coping-Meditation]] Reflecting, planning, breathing properly. Reminding myself to be here in the present moment, not get lost in the past in the future. It's what I usually do, whatever the case was.
I felt as if it hadn't happened or wasn't real
It's not like lebanon hasn't ha things like this before. -it's no 9-11. "We only live once", we live by that. I wasn't here in 14 azar, I was here in aseer - I was in Saida surrounded by troops. Going through that and the explosion now. [[Code: Experience-Prior-Violence]] And the chaos in Lebanon, you expect the worst. [[Code: Feeling-Vigilance]] It's real. It's very expected that Lebanon would go through something like that. This is what the people in power want. If they wanted something good for the country, they'd put their Ego aside and do it. [[Code: Feeling-Anger Corruption]] Everything in this country is flawed.
It's the country I'd choose over any other country. [[Code: Feeling-Patriotism]] I'd choose this country over any other country. When I came to Beirut for UNI [[Code: Feeling-Love of place]]- it helped me become the person I am. In Saudi I was molded to become the person my family/community wanted me to be. You graduate, get married, get a job and that's it. Why go back to Saudi when in Lebanon I have the freedom to be whomever I want to be and to do what I want to do [[Code: Value-Agency]] [[Code: Self-Determination]] [[Code: Needing-Control]] so I decided not to go back.

I'm dealing with them.
I had waves of strong feelings about it
When I see a picture// talk to friends about it.

I look for creative ways to alter difficult situations.
It's related to how much I value time, creativity saves a lot of time and effort. [[Code: Value-Time]]Instead of reinventing the wheel you're learning vicariously through other experiences. Creativity is very important especially as an entrepreneur. [[Code: Value-Creativity]][[Code: Value-Creativity]] "Why do you value time so much?" - time is everything Bilal. It's everything for me. It's all I have. And at the same time, it's something that I might not have. I think it stemms from depression. When you're severly depressed [[Code: Depression]] you think you're leaving. You have no purpose, what am I doing? [[Code: Loss]] You lose a sense of time. It's very dark, and vauge. - Or you don't sleep at all. I really value my experience of depression, [[Code: Silver-Linings]] it really shaped me. I don't look back and wish I didn't go through that. I'm gald it happened in that time in my life, because it woke me up. (when did it happen?) - Depressed since 14/15 (not severe) - started getting exasperated towards the last year of UNI, 20/21.
Regardless of what happens to me, I believe I can control my reaction to it.
Yeah, I mastered that. I replay events/incidents that happen in my head. I create possible scenarios that happen in my life that I //want// to happen. [[Code: Vision]] [[Code: Vision]] "Dream Believe Achive" - when you dream/think about something, give it life. You really believe in it. You gave it life by creating it, writing in your journal, saying it out loud. First experience you will be able to achieve it.
When I re-create and replay, I'm prepared. [[Code: Preparation]] [[Code: Strategic]] [[Code: Vision]] [[Code: Feeling-Empowered]]
I know how to react, with experience I know how to respond. Loud etc. On the short term - it's not the right thing to do. I should be patient calm/understanding/listen so I don't regret this tomorrow.
I believe that I can grow in positive ways by dealing with difficult situations.
I always put myself in difficult situations. [[Code: Silver-Linings]] Situations like... pitching for instance. When I'm having a normal conversation, 3adey, when I'm being put under the spotlight I get nervous. That's why I decided to pitch, and wanted to do better than I did in ACSI, this time it was more challenging. I think I did a really good job. [[Code: Learning-From Failure]]
I actively look for ways to replace the losses I encounter in life.
Depends, what kind of losses we're talking about. I always look for the lesson.[[Code: Silver-Linings]]  When I find the lesson and I know I learned something from this, khalas, I didn't lose. If I break up with a boyfriend aI don't will to replace him. I attempt to lean from the experience. I attempt to learn what kind of person I expect myself to be with in the future
How have you been coping after the blast?
I'm pretty much mostly occupied with work. [[Code: Response-Overworking]] [[Code: Response-Overworking]]
That's a way to keep that out of your head. Trying to do something for my country. [[Code: Feeling-Patriotism]] [[Placebuilding_Ideation]]  That's one way to deal with something like that. Visiting every once in a while and admiring it with all the holes in the ground/buildings that are still being renovated/ rebuilt.
Every time I visit there's a business that's back in business. There are so many businesses that said they wouldn't open anymore and they received help from investors/NGOs and they're opening up. It gives you hope

[[Concluding Statements]] [[019 Interview]]
Can you tell me a little about what has been supporting you personally and professionally since the blast?
Perks of covid 19 - People started realizing the importance of remote learning/tech in education/personalized learning at the same time. [[Code: Silver-Linings]] When people started learning about that and we were the only LMS - word of mouth really helped us. [[Code: Value-Optimism]]
They got enrolled in ringlet. increase in students at the center. Online/offline. Professionally --- Personally. My family. Supported me (mom/sister - Dad and two sisters are married in Saudi - two older sister)
What role do you see entrepreneurs having in a place like Lebanon given the current situation?
Impact, depending on the mission/vision they're trying to accomplish in Lebanon. Given the current situation.
With the revolution came many different revolutions... one of the revolutions we're making is in education. And I say that I'm an activist  [[Code: Ideation-Revolutionary]] and not in the ground - it's our revolution in education. I don't think the revolution is only about going down and doing it violently. It's about rethinking, [[Code: Value-Creativity]] unlearning, recreating. [[Code: Ideation-Revolutionary]]
Putting aside everything traditional / forced upon us / trying to make a difference. not just to make money. Money is not the aim, it's the reward. It's not the reward I'm aiming for. The impact is the aim I want. [[Code: Positive-Impact]]
There's lots, revolutions in media, education, revolution in feminism/sexuality. This awareness is coming out and have been social revolution not only (taboo). Not just a gov / political revolution, it's everything. This is my revolution.

[[History/Background]] [[020 Interview]]
Weekend Plans?
I spent time with people that I love and spent time with my family. Went to Minia. There really doesn’t feel like there’s a lock down here even. My motto for the weekend is to rest up and get ready to kick the ^*&$( of the week. (laughs)
Week plans?
Lots going on, work work work. Two big projects we’re going to work on, more focus on the learning land program. We got a project with CLS - Center of Lebanese Studies. We’re now expanding our project to all 9 districts. We’re also working on a digital teachers program. We wanted to connect people physically, and we tried as much as possible to keep the personal connection, that’s something that people really need. We went 100% online. So far it’s going well.
Can you tell me about your history with entrepreneurship?
My family, everyone has their own business, for sure, and they're all quite traditional. Although, when I was in school I had many experiences with ENJAZ Lebanon [[Code: Experience-Prior-Entrepreneurial-Training]] they joined a lot of classrooms when I was in school during grade 7, 9, 11.  I wanted to become an entrepreneur because the whole system is passive and "I want a job" - "I want to be an engineer". I don't want to be anyone else, I want to be to run my own thing that I'm completely passionate about that I purposely want to pursue and not just go with the flow.
Where does this entrepreneurial drive come from? What differentiated you from your classmates?
There are many factors. I think that I'm more self aware and that brings a lot of power to your hand and head. I think I lived through different experiences to help me reach where I am and I'm looking for more experiences to help me understand [[Code: Value-Self knowledge]]"who is [participants name referenced I worked with different non-profits that helped me, and I went to them for help because yeah, I want to be an entrepreneur although I don't have the full set of skills that I need. I worked with a different number of them. One of the things that made me more passionate for education was a program with Teach For Lebanon, it's a program a part of a global program called Teach for All.  You go and work in an underprivileged school and you learn about how the kids are suffering and you learn about so many eye opening things. [[Code: Feeling-Compassion]] [ And the whole experience gives you the feeling, if you have an entrepreneurial mindset, you need to solve all of these problems.[[Code: Altruism]] [[Code: Value-Agency]] [[Code: Feeling-Confidence]]You can't ignore it. Actually a few of the people from the fellowship have become entrepreneurs. We were only like 2-3. I tried to talk to the CEO to talk to more civil society people to train the fellows  who are in the classrooms in entrepreneurship so they can continue. It's just two years in the fellowship. [[Code: Volunteering]] [[Code: Entrepreneurship-Solution to problems]]
What experiences helped you with self awareness?
Being open to learning as much as you can. Whatever workshop, anything, jump in anything. And then know your niche and start to specialize.
Can you tell me about your decision making process when you decided to start your own business?

I like this question, it always starts informally. you start thinking about doing things, then you talk to people bring people together and one of the things I'm thinking about now is I really want to solve a problem in education and other people want to solve it and I think about it more. It's a bit critical, it's related to LGBTQ kids in school and no one wants to talk about it. So I catch friends, a psychologist, an activist, and we start this dialog. Sometimes we reach somewhere and sometimes we don't. It's important to have these discussions outside of work places sometimes that builds these spaces.
